questions.text: A 72-year-old patient, with a history of cataract surgery and diabetes mellitus, presents with decreased vision one month after surgery. Examination reveals a honeycomb appearance or flower petal pattern of the retina. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cystoid macular edema

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of 72 year old, h/o of cataract surgery, flower petal pattern of retina in examination leads to the diagnosis of CME (Cystoid macular edema)

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME)

Etiology:

  • Ocular Treatment Complications: Post-surgery (e.g., cataract extraction, retinal detachment surgery), ocular laser therapy, and topical ocular medications.
  • Retinal Vascular Disorders: Diabetic retinopathy, central and branch retinal vein occlusion, retinal telangiectasia, and hypertensive retinopathy.
  • Intraocular Inflammations: Pars planitis, uveitis.
  • Retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Vitreomacular Traction: Associated with macular epiretinal membrane (ERM) and vitreomacular traction (VMT) syndrome.
  • Systemic Diseases: Includes leukemia, chronic renal failure, and multiple myeloma.
  • Miscellaneous Causes:niacin toxicity , PG analogues (risk factor for development of CME)

Clinical Features:

  • Visual Loss: Initial minimal to moderate vision loss, potentially leading to permanent vision decrease if persistent.
  • Ophthalmoscopy: Reveals loss of foveal contour, retinal thickening, a yellow spot at the fovea, and a "honeycomb appearance" of the macula.
  • Fluorescein Angiography: Shows leakage and dye accumulation in the macular region, with a "flower petal appearance" in late frames.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Demonstrates loss of foveal depression, cystoid spaces, and overall retinal thickening.

 

Complications:

  • Long-standing CME may result in a lamellar macular hole.

Treatment:

  • Addressing the Cause: Intravitreal anti-VEGF or photocoagulation for diabetic CME; discontinuing causative topical medications.
  • Topical NSAIDs: Such as ketorolac, diclofenac, or profenac, are effective in preventing and treating CME.
  • Topical/Systemic Steroids: Useful in established cases.
  • Systemic Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors (CAIs): Oral acetazolamide may be beneficial, particularly in cases associated with retinitis pigmentosa.

Central Serous Retinopathy (Option B) is characterized by "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" leakage patterns on FFA, and neurosensory retinal and RPE detachment on OCT. CSR typically does not present with the cystoid pattern seen in CME.

Retinal detachment (Option C) Defined as the separation of the retinal pigment epithelium from neurosensory retina.

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option D): Typically shows diffuse retinal thickening and other diabetic changes, not the cystoid spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumour of the superficial parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Surgical resection

Explanation:

  • The preferred treatment for a benign tumour of the superficial parathyroid gland is surgical resection, which involves removing the tumour to avoid complications.
  • Since benign parathyroid tumours (often referred to as adenomas) can lead to conditions like hypercalcemia, surgery is usually the most effective and curative treatment.

The main modality of treatment is as follows:

Indications of parathyroidectomy:

  • Severe symptoms
  • Young age
  • Markedly reduced bone density
  • Serum calcium more than 11mg%
  • Urinary calculi
  • Neuromuscular symptoms
  • Urinary calcium more than 400mg/24 hours

Indications of surgery in an asymptomatic case are:

  • Serum calcium 0.25 mmol/L (1.0 mg/dL) above the upper limit of normal
  • Bone mineral density (BMD) by DEXA; T score –2.5 at lumbar spine, total hip, femoral neck, or distal one-third of radius
  • Vertebral fracture
  • Creatinine clearance <60 mL/min
  • 24-hour urinary calcium >10 mmol/dL (>400 mg/day) or increased risk of stone formation by risk analysis
  • Age <50 years
  • When medical therapy is not possible

Miami Protocol:

  • An intraoperative PTH is measured
  • If it has reduced by more than 50% than the preoperative value, it indicates surgical removal.

Casanova test: It is to differentiate the recurrence site after Removal of all 4 Parathyroid gland and auto transplant of it. PTH measurements are taken from the neck vein & brachial vessel.

  • A positive Casanova test is if 20 times higher concentration in the brachial vessel

Contraindications of surgery:

  • Absolute contraindication: familial hypercalciuric hypercalcemia
    • Here, elevated calcium and PTH level but 24 hr urinary calcium and calcium to creatinine clearance are low.
    • Parathyroidectomy does not cure hypercalcemia due to FHH syndrome.
  • Relative contraindications:
    • Controlateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
    • Vocal cord dysfunction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ER with complaints of epigastric pain for 1 day. On examination, his heart rate is 120/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. There is tenderness, guarding, and rigidity on palpation. Based on the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, what is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hollow viscus perforation

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and the x-ray findings that show free air under the diaphragm, which is a classic sign of perforation, suggest hollow viscus perforation.

A hollow viscus perforation occurs when there is a rupture or hole in a hollow organ (such as the stomach, small intestine, large intestine, or duodenum), allowing its contents to spill into the peritoneal cavity. This leads to peritonitis, a potentially life-threatening condition.

  • Clinical features:
    • Acute onset of severe abdominal pain, often described as sharp or stabbing.
    • Generalized peritonitis:
      • Tenderness and guarding over the entire abdomen.
      • Rigidity (board-like abdomen).
    • Tachycardia is due to pain and a systemic response to infection.
    • Hypotension due to septic shock or fluid loss into the peritoneum.
    • Nausea and vomiting are common & fever may develop as a sign of infection.
  • Causes:
    • Peptic ulcer perforation (most common cause, especially in duodenum).
    • Trauma (e.g., stab or gunshot wounds).
    • Diverticulitis leads to colonic perforation.
    • Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn’s disease).
    • Appendicitis that progresses to rupture.
    • Foreign body ingestion leads to injury or perforation.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Free air under the diaphragm (classic sign) indicates that air has escaped into the peritoneal cavity.
    • It may show air-fluid levels if associated with bowel obstruction.
  • CECT: Most sensitive to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management:
    • Surgical intervention: Exploratory laparotomy done after stabilisation.
    • Antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are started to treat peritonitis and prevent septic shock.
    • Fluid resuscitation: IV fluids are crucial to support blood pressure and organ function, especially in cases of sepsis.

Incorrect Options:

Acute cholecystitis (Option A) typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and a positive Murphy's sign, but it is less likely to present with generalised peritonitis (rigidity, guarding) or hypotension.

Sigmoid volvulus (Option C) typically presents with abdominal distension and onstipation, may show a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on X-ray.

Small bowel obstruction (Option D) can present with pain, distension, and vomiting, but the key finding in small bowel obstruction is dilated loops of bowel on X-ray, not free air (unless there is a perforation, which is less common). In cases of jejunal obstruction, valvulae conniventes, which are mucosal folds that span the entire diameter of the bowel, create a ladder effect.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with diffuse abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals rigidity and guarding. Abdominal X-ray shows air under the diaphragm. The patient is taken up for surgery, and an ileal perforation is noted intraoperatively with gross contamination of the abdomen with enteric and purulent content. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Urgent surgical exploration with ileostomy

Explanation:

  • Given the gross contamination with enteric and purulent contents, faecal diversion via ileostomy is usually recommended. This helps to prevent further contamination and allows the infected peritoneum to heal while diverting the faecal contents away from the abdomen.

Types of Stomas:

Type

Description

Common Uses

Reversibility

End Colostomy

Single opening from the proximal bowel. Often permanent.

Used when the distal bowel is removed or left in place, e.g., Hartmann's procedure

Often permanent

Loop Ileostomy

Loop of the bowel is brought to the surface, and an incision is made

Temporary diversion, especially in emergencies, and easily reversible

Usually temporary

Double-barrel Colostomy

Two stomas are created: one for faecal output and one for mucus discharge

Rarely used; can be for cases requiring both resection and exteriorization, offering mucous fistula

Can be temporary

Permanent Ileostomy

Terminal ileum is brought to the surface after a colectomy

Used when reconnection is not planned, often after total proctocolectomy for conditions like FAP

Permanent

Incorrect Options:

Resection and anastomosis (Option A) is typically used in cases of multiple perforations, malignancy, suspected gangrene, or if there is significant tissue loss. It is not recommended in cases with severe peritoneal contamination, as the risk of infection, abscess formation, and anastomotic leak is high.

Primary repair (Option B) is typically reserved for small perforations with minimal contamination and no signs of peritonitis.

Omental patch closure (Option D): While duodenal perforations are often treated with an omentum patch without resection, ileal perforations with significant contamination generally require more aggressive management, such as an ileostomy, to prevent sepsis and further complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. She has a history of epilepsy and has been on anti-epileptic medication for the past 5 years. Which of the following statements regarding folic acid supplementation in patients on anti-epileptic drugs is most accurate?

choices.text: The daily requirement of folic acid is 400 mcg/day
The daily requirement of folic acid is 4 mg/day
The daily requirement of folic acid is 1 mg/day
The daily requirement of folic acid is 500 mcg/day

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The daily requirement of folic acid is 4 mg/day

Explanation:

  • Patients on anti-epileptic medications require higher doses of folic acid
  • This is due to increased metabolism and excretion of folate
  • A replacement dose of 4000 mcg/day (4 mg/day) is recommended to mitigate the risk of deficiency

Clinical Significance:

  • Regular folic acid supplementation is crucial in patients on anti-epileptic medications
  • Proper supplementation helps prevent:
    • Neural tube defects (especially important in women of childbearing age)
    • Megaloblastic anemia
    • Other folate deficiency complications

 

Options A, C, and D suggest inadequate dosing for patients on anti-epileptic medications.

questions.text: Which mutation is linked to the Philadelphia chromosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reciprocal translocation

Explanation:

  • The Philadelphia Chromosome is a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 9 and 22 that is commonly identified in CML (chronic myeloid leukaemia).
  • The two chromosome breaks lie within:
    • ABL gene on chromosome 9
    • BCR (breakpoint cluster region) gene on chromosome 22.
  • Nonhomologous end-joining causes a reciprocal translocation, resulting in the formation of an oncogenic BCR-ABL fusion gene on the derivative chromosome 22, known as the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • BCR-ABL fusion genes encode chimeric BCR-ABL proteins with constitutive tyrosine kinase activity.

 

Inversion (Option A): In an inversion, a segment of a chromosome is flipped within the same chromosome but remains in its original location. Example of inversion-related disorder: Hemophilia A (due to intrachromosomal inversion in the F8 gene).

Deletion (Option B) involves the loss of a chromosome segment, leading to missing genetic material. Example of deletion-related disorder: Cri-du-chat syndrome (chromosome 5p deletion)

Insertion (Option D) occurs when a segment of one chromosome is inserted into another chromosome without reciprocal exchange. Example of insertion-related disorder: Some cases of hereditary cancer syndromes due to gene insertions.

questions.text: A vegetable vendor with no criminal history went missing and was found dead a week later with advanced decomposition. How would you identify the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) DNA profiling

Explanation:DNA Profiling is highly reliable and can be used even when the body is in an advanced state of decomposition.

General recognition (Option A) Due to advanced decomposition, the body’s features will be severely altered, making general recognition unreliable.

Dental records (Option C) Pre-existing dental records for comparison might not be available for a vegetable vendor, so they are not preferred.

Fingerprints (Option D) If the deceased had a criminal record, then fingerprints are more reliable to identify the body.

questions.text: A motorcyclist met with a road traffic accident and had a metacarpal fracture. Hypothenar atrophy is observed. Identify the nerve involved.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Ulnar nerve

Explanation:

  • The ulnar nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles. Any damage to the ulnar nerve in case of a metacarpal fracture can lead to hypothenar atrophy.

 

Ulnar nerve supply in the hand:

The ulnar nerve travels alongside the ulnar artery and gives off a palmar cutaneous branch before reaching the flexor retinaculum, supplying the ulnar side of the palm & enters Guyon’s canal & divides into:

  • Superficial Branch: Supplies the skin of the medial 1½ fingers & Palmaris brevis.
  • Deep Branch: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand except muscles of thenar eminence & 1st two lumbricals and terminates supplying Adductor pollicis, aka Graveyard of Ulnar nerve.

Guyon’s Canal (Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome):

  • Compression of the ulnar nerve within Guyon’s canal at the wrist.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Claw-Hand Deformity: The ring and little fingers exhibit pronounced ulnar claw hand when compared to injury of the ulnar nerve at the elbow (ulnar paradox) due to preserved function of the FDP, resulting in marked flexion of DIP joints.
    • Atrophy of the Hypothenar Eminence (Option B)
    • Loss of Finger Abduction and Adduction
    • Positive Froment’s Sign: Unable to hold the book between thumb and index indicates weakness in the adductor pollicis. DIP Of thumb compensates for adductor pollicis weakness and thumb flexion occurs.

 

Radial nerve (Options A) Damage to the radial nerve leads to wrist drop (inability to extend the wrist) and loss of elbow extension.

Musculocutaneous nerve (Options C) injury causes weakness in elbow flexion, forearm supination and shoulder flexion. Sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the forearm is also seen

Median nerve (Options D) lesion causes difficulty flexing the index and middle fingers and loss of thumb opposition, but it does not affect hypothenar eminence.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with MEN-1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Parathyroid adenoma

Explanation:

  • MEN-1 syndrome, also known as Wermer syndrome, results from a mutation in the MEN-1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. This gene mutation leads to uncontrolled mitosis in endocrine glands.
  • The classic triad of MEN-1 includes parathyroid adenoma (the most common manifestation), pancreatic adenoma, and pituitary adenoma. Parathyroid involvement is typically the first and most frequent manifestation of this syndrome.

Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia

 

MEN Type I

MEN Type II

MEN Type III

MEN Type IV

Cause
  • Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation
  • Also called Wermer’s syndrome
  • Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene
  • Also called Sipple’s syndrome

Also called MEN II B, it is a variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included

Parathyroid adenoma

(most common)

  • It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism (↑ PTH and ↑ Ca)
  • All the 4 glands can be included.
  • Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection

Parathyroid adenoma (most common, and calcium can be normal)

 

Medullary carcinoma thyroid (most common)

 

Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)

Pancreatic adenoma

  • Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
  • This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type.

Pheochromocytoma.

 

Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure.

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma

Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility

Medullary thyroid carcinoma

  • Calcitonin is the tumor marker present
  • Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan
  • Metastasis can be traced with PET scan
  • Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia
  • Rx- Prophylactic thyroidectomy

Reproductive tract tumors

  • Testicular tumors
  • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae

Occasionally with

  • Renal tumor
  • Adrenal tumor

Parotid tumor (Option B): Parotid tumors are not part of the multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes. These tumors affect the salivary glands and are not associated with endocrine disorders.

Renal cell carcinoma (Option C): While some renal manifestations may occur in MEN syndromes (such as in MEN IV), renal cell carcinoma is not a feature of MEN-1. It may be coincidentally present but is not a defining feature of the syndrome.

Pheochromocytoma (Option D): Pheochromocytoma is actually associated with MEN-II/Sipple syndrome & MEN-III, not MEN-1.

questions.text: A patient came with the complaints of fatigue and difficulty breathing. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

  • The chest X-ray showing a normal sized heart with thickened pericardium due to pericardial fibrosis/calcification (Egg in cup appearance) and classic triad of symptoms: dyspnea, distended neck veins (indicating elevated jugular venous pressure), and muffled heart sounds which indicates constrictive pericarditis.
  • This condition occurs due to fibrous or calcific constrictive thickening of the pericardium, leading to loss of pericardial elasticity and restricted ventricular filling during diastole.

Constrictive Pericarditis:

Pathophysiology:

  • Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).
  • Shows “Egg in cup appearance” on Xray

 

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

Acute pericarditis (Option A) presents with a flask-shaped, enlarged cardiac silhouette while in constrictive pericarditis, the heart is normal sized. The chest X-ray appearance is distinctly different from the egg-in-cup appearance seen in constrictive pericarditis.

Bronchial asthma (Option B) shows pulmonary hyperinflation with bronchial wall thickening. The cardiac silhouette and mediastinal structures would not show the pattern seen in this X-ray.

Atrial myxoma (Option D) typically presents with cardiomegaly, left atrial enlargement, and vascular redistribution. The X-ray findings and clinical presentation are not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: Voltage-gated calcium channel present on T-tubule is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dihydropyridine receptor

Explanation:

  • The dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), also called the L-type calcium channel, is found in the T-tubule membrane near the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) in muscle cells.
  • When an action potential travels along the T-tubule, DHPR channels open in response to voltage changes, allowing calcium ions to enter the sarcoplasm.

Sarcotubular System:

  • The Sarcotubular system is composed of the L tubule and T tubule.
  • The T-tubule contains an L-type voltage-gated Calcium channel, known as the DHPR (dihydropyridine receptor channel).
  • The L-tubule contains a calcium channel known as RyR ryanodine receptor channel (Option D)

 

 

 

SERCA pump (Option A): Sarcoplasmic/Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase is situated on the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) membrane in muscle cells, moves calcium ions (Ca2+) from the cell's cytoplasm into the SR lumen, against their concentration gradient.

Troponin-myosin complex (Option B): Troponin, a protein complex on muscle actin filaments, comprises three subunits: troponin C, troponin I, and troponin T. This complex regulates muscle contraction and relaxation by modulating actin-myosin filament interaction in response to intracellular calcium changes.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with alcoholic liver disease was given some anti-amoebic drugs. Later, the patient presented with nausea, vomiting, flushing and hypotension. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Disulfiram-like reaction

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of nausea, vomiting, flushing, and hypotension after taking an anti-amoebic drug in the context of chronic alcohol use are indicative of a disulfiram-like reaction.
  • Metronidazole is used in the treatment of amoebic colitis and liver abscesses, which has the potential to cause this reaction.
  • Metronidazole has a structural similarity to disulfiram (the drug used to help people with alcohol dependence).
  • Disulfiram works by irreversibly inhibiting ALDH, and metronidazole's action on ALDH mimics this effect, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed.

Delirium tremens (Option A) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that occurs typically 48-72 hours after the last drink in an alcoholic patient. Symptoms include confusion, hallucinations, severe agitation, and autonomic instability; it can also lead to cardiac arrhythmia.

Alcohol withdrawal (Option B) occurs when a chronic alcoholic stops drinking, typically presenting with symptoms like tremors, anxiety, insomnia, nausea, sweating, and potentially seizures. However, the presence of flushing and hypotension after taking a drug strongly points toward a disulfiram-like reaction in the given condition.

Hallucinosis (Option D) is a condition where the patient experiences visual or auditory hallucinations in the setting of acute intoxication or alcohol withdrawal, in the case of alcoholics. The patient's symptoms here are more consistent with a reaction from drug-alcohol interaction rather than hallucinations.

questions.text: A patient has a fever, rash, and eschar formation due to a mite bite. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Scrub typhus

Explanation:Scrub typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is transmitted through the bite of an infected mite (specifically the chigger mite). The hallmark features of scrub typhus include fever, rash, and eschar formation at the site of the mite bite. The eschar is a necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black center, often seen in patients with scrub typhus.

  • Rash involving the palms and soles are typically seen in the following diseases:
    • Rocky Mountain spotted fever (Rickettsia rickettsii)
    • Hand-foot-mouth disease (CoxSackie A virus)
    • Secondary syphilis

Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in scrub vegetation i.e. low-lying trees and bushes.
  • The bite of infected trombiculid mites transmits it.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

  • The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

Anthrax (Option A): Anthrax is caused by Bacillus anthracis and typically presents with a papule that ulcerates, forming an eschar, but it does not typically present with a generalized rash or fever in the same way as scrub typhus. Anthrax is more common in individuals who handle animal products.

African tick typhus (Option C): This is caused by Rickettsia africae and transmitted by tick bites. It presents similarly to scrub typhus with fever and eschar, but scrub typhus is more common in regions like Asia, whereas African tick typhus is more common in sub-Saharan Africa.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) (Option D): RMSF is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii and transmitted by tick bites. It typically presents with fever, rash, and eschar, but the rash in RMSF tends to start on the wrists and ankles and spreads centrally, unlike the rash seen in scrub typhus. It also doesn't commonly feature an eschar at the site of the tick bite.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a barking cough and noisy breathing. An anteroposterior view of x ray of the neck shows a steeple sign. What type of stridor is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Options: C) Biphasic

Explanation:

  • Croup is Laryngotracheobronchitis, which is inflammation of larynx, trachea, and bronchi
  • The stridor that happens between vocal cords and the cervical trachea is biphasic

 

Diagnosis:

  • Anteroposterior view of the neck: steeple sign due to subglottic stenosis.

Symptoms:

  • Malaise and fever: Low grade or no fever, and the child is not toxic
  • Respiratory: Biphasic stridor.
  • Digestive: Not present or mild.
  • Phonatory/ voice: Change in voice and cough, barking seal-like cough.

 

Incorrect Options:

Inspiratory (Option A): This kind of stridor is seen in inflammatory conditions that happen above the vocal cords

Expiratory (Option B): This stridor is seen when inflammation happens in the trachea, bronchi

Uniphasic (Option D): There is no such term, and it can be eliminated by explaining the above options.

questions.text: All of the below are features of Conn's syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metabolic acidosis

Explanation:

  • Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome.
    • Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by autonomous aldosterone production from the adrenal glands. The condition leads to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubules. It is characterized by Hypertension, Hypokalemia and Metabolic Alkalosis (leading to muscle cramps).
    • The pathophysiology involves excess aldosterone stimulating the ENaC channel, resulting in increased sodium and water reabsorption while promoting urinary loss of potassium and hydrogen ions.

Conn Syndrome / Primary Hyperaldosteronism

Definition

Primary hyperaldosteronism characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion from adrenal glands with suppressed plasma renin

Epidemiology
  • Most common cause of secondary hypertension (6-20% of adult hypertensive patients)
  • Higher prevalence in resistant hypertension (up to 30%)
  • 2x more common in women

Etiology
  • Aldosterone-producing adenoma (50-60%)
  • Bilateral idiopathic adrenal hyperplasia
  • Aldosterone-producing adrenal carcinoma (1%)
  • Familial hyperaldosteronism (Types 1-3)

Pathophysiology
  • ↑ Aldosterone → ↑ Na+ reabsorption → plasma volume expansion
  • ↑ K+ excretion → hypokalemia
  • Can lead to tissue inflammation and fibrosis in heart, kidneys, vasculature

Clinical Features
  • Resistant hypertension
  • Muscle weakness/cramping
  • Fatigue
  • Headaches
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • NO edema (due to spontaneous natriuresis)

Lab Findings
  • ↓ K+ (can be normal in up to 38%)
  • ↑ Na+
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • ↑ Urinary K+ excretion (>30 mmol/day)
  • Suppressed plasma renin
  • ↑ Aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR)

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Initial screening: ARR >40
  • Confirmatory tests:
    • Salt loading test
    • Fludrocortisone suppression test
    • Captopril suppression test
  • Imaging: CT scan for adenoma
  • Adrenal venous sampling for lateralization

Treatment
  • Adenoma: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Bilateral hyperplasia: Medical management
  • Medical options:
    • Spironolactone (first-line)
    • Eplerenone
    • Amiloride

Prognosis
  • Surgery: 30-60% cure rate for adenomas
  • High morbidity/mortality if untreated
  • May need long-term BP monitoring

High-Yield Associations
  • Normal K+ doesn't exclude diagnosis
  • No edema despite hyperaldosteronism
  • Screen all resistant hypertension cases

Metabolic alkalosis (Option A) is a characteristic feature of Conn's syndrome. This occurs due to increased urinary loss of hydrogen ions and bicarbonate retention, leading to alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis is actually one of the hallmark features of this condition.

Hypertension (Option C) is a primary manifestation of Conn's syndrome. This develops due to increased sodium and water reabsorption leading to volume expansion. The increased blood volume and sodium retention directly contribute to elevated blood pressure.

Muscle cramps (Option D) are commonly seen in patients with Conn's syndrome. These occur due to hypokalemia. The low potassium levels affect muscle function and can lead to weakness, fatigue, and cramping.

questions.text: Aromatic ring is seen in which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Phenylalanine, tryptophan, tyrosine

Explanation

Classification of amino acids based on the functional group:

 

Amino acids

Examples

Basic amino acids

Arginine, Lysine, Histidine (Option D ruled out)

Acidic amino acids

Aspartic acid, Glutamic acid

OH group-containing amino acids

Serine, Threonine, Tyrosine

SH group-containing amino acids

Cysteine, Methionine (Option C, D ruled out)

NH2 group-containing amino acids

Asparagine, Glutamine

Aromatic amino acids

(Option B)

Phenylalanine, Tyrosine, Tryptophan, Histidine

Aliphatic amino acid

Glycine, Alanine,

Branched chain AA (Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine) (Option A, D ruled out)

Imino acid

Proline

questions.text: What type of sanitation facilities should be provided for the soldiers returning from war?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Trench latrine

Explanation:

  • Trench latrine facilities serve as vital sanitation solutions, particularly in military environments.
  • These setups involve excavating elongated trenches in the ground, fortified with materials to prevent cave-ins, and equipped with seating or similar structures for soldier utilization. They offer a straightforward and efficient means of waste disposal, particularly suited for temporary or field conditions.

Key features of a basic trench latrine include:

  • Trench dimensions typically measure 30 cm in width, with depths ranging from 90 to 150 cm, and lengths spanning 3 to 3.5 meters. Such specifications are designed to accommodate approximately 100 individuals efficiently.
  • To uphold privacy and comfort, separate trench latrines are designated for male and female soldiers.
  • Users are instructed to cover their waste with soil after each use, ensuring the maintenance of hygiene and sanitation standards within the facility.

Incorrect Options:

Pit method (Option A):

  • The pit method involves digging a hole or pit in the ground for waste disposal. While similar to trench latrines, pit latrines typically have deeper holes and may not be as suitable for military settings due to the need for frequent relocation and potential health hazards.

Dumping method (Option B):

  • The dumping method typically refers to the disposal of waste in designated areas, such as waste disposal sites or landfills. This method may not be appropriate for soldiers returning from war, as it lacks privacy and sanitation measures.

Acqua privy (Option D):

  • An acqua privy is a type of water-based toilet system that uses water to flush waste away. While common in civilian settings, acqua privies may not be practical or feasible for military deployments, especially in remote or austere environments.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for ovarian torsion is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) USG Doppler

Explanation:

  • USG Doppler is the investigation of choice for diagnosing ovarian torsion due to its ability to assess ovarian blood flow and morphology. It is non-invasive, readily available, and provides real-time assessment without radiation exposure.

USG findings in ovarian torsion:

  • Ovarian appearance: Swollen and edematous
  • Shape: Globular configuration
  • Additional findings: Free fluid in the peritoneal cavity
  • Blood flow: Disruption in normal adnexal flow

 

Clinically correlated (Option B) is important but cannot be used as the sole diagnostic method, as symptoms vary and imaging is required for confirmation.

MRI (Option C) is not the first-line investigation as it is time-consuming, not suitable in emergencies, and less readily available.

CT abdomen (Option D) is not ideal for gynecologic emergencies due to radiation exposure, less specificity, and time-consuming nature.

questions.text: A 10 year old child is brought to the clinic for his regular immunization. What vaccine is given as a part of the national immunization schedule?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) TT/Td

Explanation:

  • TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus-diphtheria) vaccine is given as a part of the immunization program for a 10-year-old school child.
  • TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus-diphtheria) vaccine: The TT/Td vaccine is given to provide protection against tetanus and diphtheria. It is often administered as a booster dose every 10 years to maintain immunity. At the age of 10, a child may receive a TT/Td vaccine as a part of their routine immunization schedule.

National Immunization Schedule:

Time

Vaccines

At birth

BCG, OPV0 (OPV birth dose), Hep B (birth dose)

6 weeks

OPV1, Penta1, RVV1, fIPV1, PCV1

10 weeks

OPV2, Penta2, RVV2

14 weeks

OPV3, Penta3, RVV3, fIPV2, PCV2

9 completed months

MR1, JE1, PCV booster, fIPV3, vitamin A

16-24 months

MR2, JE2, OPV booster, DPT booster 1

5-6 years

DPT booster 2

10 years

Td

16 years

Td

Incorrect Options:

BCG (Option B): The BCG vaccine is typically given at birth or during infancy to protect against tuberculosis. It is not part of the immunization program for a 10-year-old child.

MMR (Option C): The MMR vaccine is usually administered around 12-15 months of age and a second dose at 4-6 years of age. It protects against measles, mumps, and rubella. By the age of 10, most children would have already received the recommended doses of the MMR vaccine.

DTP (Option D): The DPT vaccine is typically given during infancy and early childhood to protect against diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough), and tetanus. By the age of 10, children would have already completed the recommended doses of the DPT vaccine series.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient diagnosed with hollow viscus perforation is taken up for laparotomy. Intraoperatively, a 2 cm perforation is seen in the duodenal region, as shown below. How can this patient be managed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Omental pedicle repair

Explanation:

  • In case of a duodenal perforation, omental pedicle repair is the preferred method of treatment. The omentum, a highly vascular tissue, is mobilised and placed over the perforation. This provides a biological seal and promotes healing while reducing the risk of infection or further leakage.

Duodenal ulcer perforation:

  • Common with anterior duodenal ulcers.
  • Presents with an acute abdomen with sudden-onset, severe epigastric pain, rebound tenderness, and air under the diaphragm in the radiograph.

Management:

  • Non-surgical:
    • Nil per-oral
    • IV antibiotics and PPIs
  • Surgical:
    • Initial empirical antibiotic treatment.
    • The perforation is approached by a small upper midline incision
  • Perforations <1cm are closed primarily and buttressed with a well-vascularized omentum
  • Larger perforations & with fibrotic edges: Modified Graham's Repair or Omental Patch Repair.
  • The vascularized pedicle of the greater omentum is patched over the defect.

Bleeding duodenal ulcer:

  • A posterior duodenal ulcer is the one that usually bleeds.
  • It is due to the involvement of the gastroduodenal artery.
  • This leads to hematemesis, melena or both i.e., an upper GI bleed.
  • Bleeding is commonly associated with intake of NSAIDs.

Management:

  • Endoscopic: Done to find the bleeding source and manage bleeds endoscopically. Injection, thermal coagulation, plasma argon coagulation, mechanical clips, and fibrin glue are the methods used. (with or without adrenaline injection).
  • Angiographic management: If endoscopic management fails.
  • Surgical management:
    • Exposure to the ulcer and ligation of the duodenum are the principles here.
    • Duodenotomy
    • Ligation of the bleeding vessel with truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy, and abdominal pain. She also has a history of mood disorders and recurrent kidney stones. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Angiography of renal arteries

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms, including polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy, abdominal pain, and a history of recurrent kidney stones, strongly suggest a diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism, which can result in hypercalcemia.
  • The most likely cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a parathyroid adenoma.
  • Angiography of renal arteries is typically used to evaluate the renal vasculature in cases of renal artery stenosis or other vascular abnormalities. However, it does not provide useful information for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.

Incorrect Options:

Nuclear sestamibi scan (Option A) is used to identify parathyroid adenomas. It is a key investigation in the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism, especially in localising the adenoma.

USG neck (Option B) can also help in visualising parathyroid glands and is commonly used for parathyroid adenomas.

Dual energy radiographic absorptiometry (DEXA) (Option C) is a test used to assess bone density and is often ordered to evaluate for osteoporosis, which is common in primary hyperparathyroidism due to bone resorption from elevated calcium.

questions.text: What is the role of inhibin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inhibits the secretion of FSH

Explanation:

  • Inhibin from the granulosa cells inhibits FSH secretion.
  • It is a hormone primarily produced by the ovaries (in females) and testes (in males).
  • It regulates the reproductive system by inhibiting the secretion of FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) from the anterior pituitary gland.
  • Inhibin suppresses the FSH
    • Inhibin B: Before ovulation
    • Inhibin A: After ovulation

 

Stimulates the secretion of FSH (Option A): Inhibin does not stimulate FSH release; instead, it inhibits it. FSH is involved in the growth and maturation of reproductive cells, but inhibin reduces its secretion once the follicle or sperm production reaches sufficient levels.

Inhibition of PRL (Option C) and Stimulation of PRL (Option D): Inhibin does not directly regulate prolactin (PRL), a hormone involved in milk production. PRL levels are primarily controlled by dopamine from the hypothalamus and other factors, not by inhibin. Therefore, inhibin neither inhibits nor stimulates PRL production.

questions.text: Feature of angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis is seen in which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Riboflavi

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency, characterized by the classic triad of angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis.
  • This vitamin plays a crucial role in cellular energy metabolism and maintaining the integrity of mucocutaneous surfaces.
  • The deficiency typically manifests with inflammation of the lips (cheilosis), painful lesions at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), and inflammation of the tongue (glossitis)
  • Additional manifestations include seborrheic dermatitis along nasolabial folds and photophobia.

 

Vitamin B2 Deficiency

 

Riboflavin (B2) deficiency

Cause
  • Malnutrition
  • Malabsorption
  • Certain medications
  • Phototherapy

Clinical features:

Cheilosis, glossitis, keratitis, conjunctivitis, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia, photophobia.

Diagnosis:

Clinical response to supplementation, EGR (Erythrocyte Glutathione Reductase) activity test, low urinary riboflavin.

Treatment:

Oral riboflavin 3-10 mg/day, balanced diet including dairy products

 

Niacin (Vitamin B3) (Option A) deficiency presents as pellagra, characterized by the 4 D's: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death if untreated. While it can affect the mucous membranes, the classic triad of oral manifestations is not its primary presentation.

Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) (Option C) deficiency primarily presents with megaloblastic anemia and neurological manifestations, including subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. Oral manifestations are not the predominant feature.

Vitamin C (Option D) deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and petechial hemorrhages. While it can affect oral mucosa, it does not cause the specific triad of angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis.

questions.text: A child was diagnosed with Turner syndrome. Which of the following are features of Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Webbed neck

Explanation:

  • The image shows a webbed neck, which is a characteristic feature of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome (45, XO) is a chromosomal disorder characterized by the absence of one X chromosome in females.

 

Turner syndrome has multiple clinical manifestations that can be categorized using the SABLCOWN mnemonic:

Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome (Mnemonic- SABCLOWN)

S
  • Short stature
  • Short 4th metacarpal
  • Sensorineural hearing loss

A
  • Amenorrhea (Primary)

B
  • Barr body absent

C
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Cubitus valgus

L
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Lymphedema of hands and feet
  • Low thyroid (Hypothyroidism)

O
  • Ovaries streak-shaped/underdeveloped
  • Rudimentary uterus

W
  • Webbed neck

N
  • Nipples are widely spaced on a shield-shaped chest
  • Normal intelligence

 

Normal height (Option B): Short stature is a cardinal feature of Turner syndrome. Growth failure typically becomes evident by age 3-5 years, and final adult height is significantly reduced without growth hormone therapy.

Decreased carrying angle (Option C): Turner syndrome is characterized by an increased carrying angle (cubitus valgus), not a decreased angle. This increased carrying angle is one of the characteristic skeletal manifestations of the condition.

Gynecomastia (Option D): Gynecomastia is not a feature of Turner syndrome. Gynecomastia is associated with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY). Turner syndrome typically presents with widely spaced nipples on a shield-shaped chest.

questions.text: Which of the following is the next appropriate step in management after the failure of the McRobert maneuver in a case of shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Suprapubic pressure

Explanation:

  • Shoulder dystocia occurs when shoulders fail to deliver with easy pulling within 60 seconds after delivery of the fetal head
  • Suprapubic pressure (also known as Rubin's maneuver) is applied if the McRoberts maneuver fails to deliver the shoulders
  • Suprapubic pressure can release an impacted anterior shoulder

 

Woods maneuver (Option A): This rotational maneuver is performed after failed suprapubic pressure, not immediately after McRoberts. The Woods maneuver involves rotating the posterior shoulder 180 degrees toward the fetal back and is considered a third-line intervention.

Gaskin maneuver (Option B): Moving the mother to all-fours position is attempted after failure of anterior maneuvers. While effective, it requires time to reposition the mother and is not the immediate next step after McRoberts failure.

Zavanelli maneuver (Option D): This is a last-resort emergency procedure involving cephalic replacement followed by cesarean delivery. It carries significant fetal and maternal morbidity and is only considered when all other maneuvers have failed.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman discovers a well-defined mobile and rubbery breast lump measuring 4x7 cm on self-examination. The lesion is painless and has been stable over several months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fibroadenoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation along with histopathology showing epithelial ducts compressed and distorted by surrounding stroma, is characteristic of an intracanalicular Fibroadenoma.

Fibroadenoma

Definition
  • Benign tumours arising from the proliferation of glandular tissue in the breast

Prevalence
  • Most common in women aged 15-25 years.

Aetiology
  • Believed to be influenced by hormonal fluctuations during reproductive years
  • Molecular alteration: Alterations in MED12 gene.

Clinical Presentation
  • Painless, firm, rubbery, and mobile lumps
  • Described as feeling like a "marble in the breast."

Histopathology

  • Well-defined borders due to a fibrous capsule, with proliferating stroma potentially compressing and distorting glandular components.
  • The epithelium may be of 2 patterns:
    • Pericanalicular Pattern: Surrounded by stroma
    • Intracanalicular Pattern: Compressed and distorted by it.

Mammogram

Popcorn calcification on mammogram

Diagnosis
  • Triple Assessment: Clinical examination, radiological imaging (ultrasound), tissue sampling (core-needle biopsy)
  • Ultrasound: Helps distinguish fibroadenomas from cysts
  • Core-Needle Biopsy: Provides definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Watchful waiting, regular monitoring
  • Surgical Excision: For larger fibroadenomas, those causing symptoms, or uncertain diagnosis
  • Giant Fibroadenomas: Over 5 cm, may require excision through submammary incision

Prognosis
  • Benign, does not increase the risk of breast cancer
  • Growth can vary, influenced by hormonal changes
  • Recurrence is uncommon

Relationship to ANDI
  • Categorised according to ANDI as:
    • Normal: Small fibroadenomas (≤1 cm)
    • Disorder: Larger fibroadenomas (≤3 cm)
    • Disease: Giant fibroadenomas (>3 cm), multiple fibroadenomas

 

Acute mastitis (Option A) is a breast infection, common in lactating women, presenting with pain, redness, swelling, and fever. It is caused by a bacterial infection but is unlikely here due to the absence of pain and inflammation.

Ductal ectasia (Option C) is a benign condition in older women, causing nipple discharge, nipple retraction, and breast tenderness. It does not present as a well-defined, mobile, painless lump, making it an unlikely diagnosis here.

Sclerosing adenosis (Option D) is a benign breast condition causing firm, palpable lumps, often associated with pain and calcifications. It is not typically mobile or rubbery, making it a less likely diagnosis.

questions.text: In solid organ transplantation, which of the following organs is associated with a higher incidence of rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lungs

Explanation:

  • Survival after lung transplantation continues to improve over time; however, the rates remain lower compared to other solid organ transplants.
  • Around 50% of lung transplant recipients will face at least one episode of acute rejection within the first year.
  • Furthermore, by five years post-transplant, roughly half of recipients will have developed chronic rejection.

Incorrect Options:

Kidney transplantation: (Option C)

  • Graft rejection rate for kidney transplants is quite low after the first year. Specifically, with living-donor kidneys, the 1-year survival rate is 98%, and with deceased-donor kidneys, the 1-year survival rate is 93%.
  • At 5 years, the graft survival rate for living-donor kidneys is 85%, and for deceased-donor kidneys, it is 75%. By 10 years, the survival rates drop to 65% for living-donor kidneys and 48% for deceased-donor kidneys, indicating a gradual decline due to chronic processes rather than acute rejection episodes.

Liver transplantation (Option D): Chronic rejection occurs in about 13-17% of recipients

Intestinal transplantation (Option B): Chronic rejection occurs in about 10% of recipients.

questions.text: After confirming a diagnosis of gout, which of the following drugs is a purine analog that would be most appropriate for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Allopurinol

Explanation:

  • Allopurinol is the first-line choice for gout management. It is a purine analog that acts as a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, effectively reducing uric acid production.

The drug works through dual mechanisms: direct inhibition of xanthine oxidase and competition with phosphoribosylpyrophosphate in the salvage pathway.

Allopurinol:

  • Allopurinol is the first-line treatment for the prevention of gouty arthritis, particularly in patients who are overproducers of uric acid.
  • The initial dose is typically 100 mg daily, with a target urate level of <5-6 mg/dL and can be titrated up to 800 mg as needed.
  • In patients with renal impairment, dose adjustments are essential.
  • Adverse effects:
    • Stevens-Johnson syndrome
    • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
    • Acute gout flare-up, which may occur due to rapid urate level reduction
  • To prevent flare-ups, anti-inflammatory therapy should be continued until the patient is normouricemic and has not had an attack for 3-6 months.

 

Capecitabine (Option B) is a pyrimidine analog used in breast cancer treatment. This medication has no role in gout management and does not affect uric acid metabolism.

Cytarabine (Option C) is a cytosine arabinoside and pyrimidine analog used in chemotherapy. It is not indicated for gout treatment and does not influence uric acid levels.

Febuxostat (Option D) is also a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. While effective for gout, it is not a purine analog.

questions.text: In cases of alcohol abuse, in what substance is the blood typically preserved during an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Sodium fluoride

Explanation: For toxic analysis, like in alcohol abuse, the ideal preservative for blood is sodium fluoride.

Various methods of preserving viscera:

  • Saturated salt solution
  • Formalin fixation
  • Freezing
  • Alcohol preservation
  • Formaldehyde solution
  • Formalin-alcohol solution
  • Frozen section
  • Liquid nitrogen

Specimens for Analysis

Specimen

Importance

Blood

Primary specimen; collect from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins to avoid contamination.

Preservative: Lithium heparin or EDTA tube, fluoride/oxalate, if alcohol is suspected

 

Urine

Useful for detecting parent compounds and metabolites of poisons.

Preservative: No preservative, sodium fluoride is added, if alcohol is

Suspected (Option A)

 

Gastric Contents

Helps identify ingested poisons and their concentrations through vomitus and stomach contents analysis.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison.(Option D)

Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid (Option C)

.

Liver

Analyzes metabolism and concentration of drugs; critical when blood/urine concentrations are low. Bile can detect specific substances like chlorpromazine and morphine.

Preservative: Saturated salt solution if there is no chance of acid poison. Rectified spirit if poisoned by acid.

Hair and Nails

Detects heavy metal poisoning; metals accumulate in keratin. Neutron activation analysis identifies specific metals and exposure patterns.

Scene Residues

Provides clues about the poison through materials found at the scene, such as tablets or empty containers.

Formalin (Option B) is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses.

questions.text: Which malarial drug for plasmodium vivax drug is used to prevent relapse in the post-partum period?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Primaquine

Explanation:

  • Primaquine is specifically used in the post-partum period of malarial infection with P. vivax.

 

Artemether (Option A): This medication is primarily used in combination with lumefantrine for acute treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria. While effective against blood stages, it does not prevent P. vivax relapses as it has no activity against hypnozoites.

Quinine (Option C): Although safe during pregnancy, quinine acts only on blood-stage parasites and cannot prevent relapses. It is primarily used for treating acute malaria episodes during pregnancy when other options are contraindicated.

Artesunate (Option D): Intravenous artesunate is the preferred treatment for severe malaria but does not prevent P. vivax relapses. It is used in life-threatening cases during pregnancy but has no effect on hypnozoites.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the treatment of Datura poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Physostigmine

Explanation:

  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for Datura poisoning because it is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor..
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centers of the brain and then activates the motor centers. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centers in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dryness of mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
    • Photophobia + Diplopia
    • Agitation and restlessness
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Dry and hot skin
    • Exfoliation of skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Toxins and Antidotes:

Toxicity

Antidote

Mechanism of action

Datura/anticholinergics toxicity

Physostigmine (Option A)

Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme

Opium

Naloxone

Opioid receptor antagonist

Organophosphates

Atropine (Option B)

Pralidoxime

Muscarinic antagonist

Cholinesterase reactivation

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl-cysteine

Replenishes Glutathione

Methanol

Fomepizole

Inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase

Benzodiazepine

Flumazenil

Inhibits GABA receptors

Cyanide

Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach)

1. Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide.

2. Sodium nitrate (Option C): causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.

  • Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given.

3. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate.

Neostigmine (Option D) does not cross blood brain barrier

questions.text: The subcostal line corresponds to which vertebrae level?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) L3

Explanation:

  • The subcostal line corresponds to the L3 vertebrae.
  • The subcostal plane refers to a horizontal (or transverse) plane which lies just below the level of the costal margin, i.e., connecting the 10th costal cartilages of right and left sides with each other.
  • Posteriorly, the position of subcostal plane equates to the body of the third lumbar (L3) vertebrae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a positive india ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cryptococcus neoformans

Explanation:

The patient’s presentation of persistent headaches, confusion, gradual onset of fever, and the findings from the lumbar puncture (elevated opening pressure and a positive India ink stain) strongly suggest cryptococcal meningitis, which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans.

Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen that commonly causes meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. The hallmark of cryptococcal meningitis in a CSF analysis is the positive India ink stain, which reveals the characteristic encapsulated yeast cells. The elevated opening pressure on lumbar puncture is also a typical finding in this infection.

Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis.

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

 

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci.

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

Bacterial meningitis (Option A): Bacterial meningitis would usually show neutrophilic predominance in the CSF, along with a much more rapid onset of symptoms. It also typically does not result in a positive India ink stain, which is specific to fungal infections like cryptococcosis.

Viral meningitis (Option B): This would generally show lymphocytic predominance in the CSF and would not give a positive India ink stain. The clinical presentation of viral meningitis is often less severe than what is seen in this case.

Tuberculous meningitis (Option D): Tuberculous meningitis can cause a similar presentation with elevated opening pressure and CSF abnormalities, but it would not be detected by India ink staining. Additionally, it would show lymphocytic predominance and might require acid-fast bacilli staining or PCR for diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient was admitted with complaints of tachycardia and arrhythmias. On examination, multiple scratch marks were observed on the body. The probable drug of abuse in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Cocaine

Explanation: Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system (CNS) stimulant known for causing tachycardia and arrhythmias, which are common symptoms associated with its abuse.

Magnan's Syndrome:

Aso known as "Cocaine Bugs," occurs in individuals who use cocaine.

It is a type of tactile hallucination where the person experiences the sensation of grains of sand or small insects crawling under the skin, causing itching (formication).

Formication is derived from the Latin word formica, meaning "ant," and refers to the feeling that tiny insects are moving across the skin.

Causes:

  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Menopause
  • Skin cancer
  • Herpes zoster
  • Physical or psychological side effect of substance abuse, including cocaine, amphetamines, and alcohol withdrawal (along with delirium tremens).

Options B, C, and D are not associated with Magnan syndrome

questions.text: Identify the arrow-marked chamber?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right ventricle

Explanation:

  • The structure marked in the above scan is the right ventricle.
  • Level of the Thoracic Inlet: This is at the top of the thoracic cavity, where the trachea and esophagus enter.
  • Level of the Aortic Arch: Located around the T4-T5 vertebral level, where the aorta arches over the left main bronchus.
  • Level of the Carina: At the T5-T6 level, this is where the trachea bifurcates into the right and left main bronchi.
  • Level of the Heart: The heart is typically seen from T6 to T9. You can identify the chambers (right atrium, left atrium, ventricles) and major vessels (aorta, pulmonary arteries).
  • Level of the Diaphragm: The diaphragm typically corresponds to the T10 vertebral level, which can help in distinguishing between thoracic and abdominal structures.
  • Level of the Esophagus: The esophagus runs along the midline and can be seen at various levels, usually starting from the cervical region down to T10.
  • Level of the Thoracic Spine: The thoracic vertebrae can be used as references; typically, there are 12 thoracic vertebrae.

questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker presents with ulcerative lesions on his lower lip for the past year. On examination, there is a palpable ipsilateral submental lymph node approximately 5x5 cm. A biopsy from the lesion is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND

Explanation:

  • Resection of the primary lesion with lip reconstruction is necessary for the treatment of primary cancer, and given the presence of a palpable lymph node (suggesting potential nodal metastasis), modified radical neck dissection (MRND) is indicated to address any possible regional nodal spread.

TNM Staging of Carcinoma lip:

T Stage

  • Tis: Carcinoma in situ
  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm and ≤5 mm depth of invasion
  • T2: Tumor ≤2 cm and >5 mm but ≤10 mm depth, OR
    Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm and ≤10 mm depth
  • T3: Tumor >4 cm OR any tumor >10 mm depth of invasion
  • T4: Invasion of adjacent structures

N Stage:

  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N1-N3: Based on number, size, and laterality of involved nodes

M Stage:

  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis

 

Management of Carcinoma lip:

Early Stage (T1-T2N0)
  • Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
  • Consider elective neck dissection for tumours>2 cm or >4 mm in depth
  • Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts

Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+)
  • Wide local excision with ≥1 cm margins
  • Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status)
  • Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer)
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings

Reconstruction Options
  • Wedge excision and primary closure (for small lesions)
  • Local flaps: Abbe-Estlander, Karapandzic, nasolabial
  • Regional flaps: Forehead, cervicofacial
  • Free tissue transfer: Radial forearm free flap, anterolateral thigh flap

Management of the Neck
  • Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumours (>2 cm, >4 mm depth)
  • Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes
  • Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck

Radiotherapy
  • Adjuvant: For positive margins, perineural invasion, multiple positive nodes
  • Definitive: For patients unfit for surgery or refusing surgery
  • Brachytherapy: Can be considered for select early-stage lesions

Chemotherapy
  • Not routinely used in early-stage disease
  • It may be combined with radiotherapy in locally advanced cases

Follow-up and Surveillance

Regular follow-up visits: Every 1-3 months for the first year, then gradually decreasing frequency

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with hypertension has been prescribed Drug X, which has a bioavailability of 30%. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement for this patient's drug prescription?

choices.text: 70% of drugs reach systemic circulation in unchanged form
70% of drugs is potent in giving therapeutic effect
70% of the drug undergoes 1st pass metabolism in the liver

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 70% of the drug undergoes 1st pass metabolism in the liver

Explanation:

  • Bioavailability is the fraction of an orally administered drug that reaches the systemic circulation in its unchanged form.
  • 30% bioavailability means that only 30% of the drug reaches the bloodstream unmetabolized. (Option A ruled out)
  • The remaining 70% of the drug is either metabolized by the liver (during the first pass through the liver) or is otherwise eliminated before it can reach the systemic circulation.
  • When a drug is taken orally, it first passes through the liver via the portal circulation, where it is partially metabolized before entering the systemic circulation. This is known as the first-pass metabolism.

30% of the drug is pure (Option B): This is incorrect because Bioavailability refers to the portion of the drug that reaches the bloodstream in unchanged form, not the "purity" of the drug.


70% of drug is potent in giving therapeutic effect (Option C): This statement misinterprets bioavailability. Potency refers to the drug's ability to produce a therapeutic effect at a given dose, not the percentage that reaches systemic circulation.

questions.text: Gold standard investigation for endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HPE

Explanation:

  • HPE is the gold standard investigation for definitively diagnosing/confirming endometriosis. It shows blood-filled macrophages (hemosiderophages) in visualization.

 

Investigations for Endometriosis:

  • Ultrasonography (TVS and ERUS) (Option C): Initial investigation, where endometrioma appears as ground glass opacities and hemorrhagic cysts appear as thread-like structures.
  • Laparoscopy (Option B): Investigation of choice, with new lesions visualised as red flame-like and chronic lesions as powder-burnt appearance.
  • Histopathology: Gold standard for confirming the diagnosis, showing blood-filled macrophages (hemosiderophages).
  • MRI (Option D): This is not routinely done but is accurate for diagnosing deep-infiltrating endometriosis (DIE), such as Bowel, Thoracic, Bladder, and Rectovaginal endometriosis, and is done before laparoscopy.
  • CA 125 Assay: Non-specific marker, often elevated in endometriosis.
  • Laparotomy: Not done for confirmatory purposes due to its invasiveness and higher risk of complications.

questions.text: At what age does stranger anxiety appear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 7 months

Explanation:

  • Stranger anxiety is an important social milestone in infant development which appears around 6-7 months of age

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his scalp for 8 years. He has a history of electric burns to the scalp 8 years ago. The examination findings are shown below. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
Long-duration antibiotics will improve the condition.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

Chronic non-healing ulcers, especially those resulting from burn injuries or other trauma, are at high risk of malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). This is known as Marjolin's ulcer, which can develop in areas of chronic injury or scar tissue.

Marjolin’s Ulcer

Definition
  • Low-grade Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Common Sites of Development
  • Post-burn scar
  • Long-standing venous ulcer
  • Chronic ulcer due to trauma
  • Chronic discharging osteomyelitis sinus
  • Post-radiation ulcer

Pathophysiology
  • Develops in scar tissue due to chronic irritation

Characteristic Features
  • Painless (no nerves in scar tissues)
  • Slow growing
  • No regional LN metastasis (no lymphatics in scar tissue)

Investigation of Choice

Biopsy

Management
  • Wide local excision followed by a flap cover
  • Radiotherapy should be avoided (Option A) (as it is radio-resistant and also to prevent obliterative end arteritis)
  • Malignant lesions like squamous cell carcinoma can spread via lymphatic channels (Option C), particularly if left untreated.
  • While antibiotics may help treat an infected ulcer, a chronic non-healing ulcer with a history of burn injury is unlikely to respond to antibiotics alone (Option D).

questions.text: What is the most likely stage of TB hip in a female with left leg shortening?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Stage 3

Explanation:

  • Stage 3 is characterized by significant destruction of the articular surface of the hip joint. In this stage, true shortening of the leg occurs due to the destruction and deformity of the joint structure.

 

Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification

Stage

Clinical Findings

X-ray findings

Stage I: Synovitis (Option A)
  • Irritable hip
  • Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation)
  • Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis)
  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

Stage II: Early Arthritis (Option B)

 
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis (Option C)
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation/severe arthritis (Option D )
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.
  • End stage of TB hip/arthritis: Fibrous ankylosis
  • End stage of TB spine: Bony ankylosis

questions.text: What is the gold standard method for measuring intraocular pressure in patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Goldmann applanation tonometer

Explanation:

Types of Tonometry:

1. Indentation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP by how much a plunger indents the eye; softer eyes indent more than harder eyes.
  • Schiotz Tonometer:
    • Most widely used tonometer in the world.
    • Advantages: Inexpensive, simple, and reliable.
    • Disadvantages: Gives false readings in eyes with abnormal scleral rigidity (e.g., high myopes, post-surgery).

2. Applanation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP based on the force needed to flatten the cornea's surface (Imbert-Fick Law: P = W/A).
  • Goldmann Tonometer (Option B):
    • Most popular and accurate; uses a double prism on a slit lamp.
    • Technique:
      • Cornea is anesthetized and stained with fluorescein.
      • Cornea and biprisms are illuminated with cobalt blue light.
      • The prism touches the cornea, and the inner edges of two semicircles are adjusted to just touch.
      • IOP is read by multiplying the dial reading by ten.

Variable force tonometers:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometer → Gold standard
  • Perkins tonometer (hand held version of goldmann)
  • Draeger tonometer (measures wide range of IOP)
    • Draeger tonometer is similar to Perkins
    • It has a different set of prisms
    • It operates with a motor
  • Pulsair (non-contact tonometer)
  • Airpuff (non-contact tonometer)
  • Grolman (non-contact tonometer)
  • Tonopen (based on both indentation and applanation) (Option D)
  • MacKay Marg (based on both indentation and applanation)
  • Rebound tonometer
  • Transpalpebral Tonometer

Fixed force tonometer:

  1. Maklakov tonometer
  2. Barraquer tonometer

Hertel’s exophthalmometer (Option A) is used to measure the degree of exophthalmos (protrusion of the eyeball) in conditions such as thyroid eye disease.

Gonioscope (Option B) is a specialized lens used to visualize the iridocorneal angle, which is important in assessing angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of bone pain for several months. His X-ray skull is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Paget’s disease

Explanation:

  • Paget’s disease is characterized by the progressive replacement of normal bone with disorganized, vascular, spongy bone, resulting from excessive osteoclastic activity followed by increased osteoblastic activity. It presents with a distinctive "cotton wool" appearance on an X-ray of the skull.

 

Clinical Features of Paget’s disease:

Asymptomatic in most cases: Often discovered incidentally via X-rays or elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP).

Symptoms:

  • Persistent, dull aching pain, which worsens at night or in warmth.
  • Deformities:
    • Lower limb deformities: Tibia bows anteriorly, femur anterolaterally, resulting in a thickened, bent limb.
    • Skull involvement:
      • Enlargement may cause tight-fitting hats.
      • Skull base flattening (platybasia) - gives a shortened neck appearance.

X-ray Findings in Paget's Disease of Bone:

Flame shaped lucency of tibia

Disease Phase

X-ray Findings

Early (osteolytic) phase
  • Localised bone resorption often appears as "flame-shaped" lesions along the bone shaft. (Option C)
  • The skull may show osteoporosis circumscripta (well-defined areas of bone loss).

Later stages
  • Bone thickening and sclerosis with coarse trabecular patterns.
  • Stress fractures are visible as fine cracks on the convex surface of long bones.
  • Pathological fractures may be present.”

 

Looser zones : Looser zones, also known as pseudofractures, are characteristic of osteomalacia or rickets. These are incomplete fractures due to defective bone mineralisation.

Sunburst pattern : This is seen in osteosarcoma, where aggressive bone growth produces a characteristic spiculated appearance due to new bone formation.

Ground-glass appearance: This is typically associated with fibrous dysplasia, where bone appears hazy due to disorganised fibrous tissue replacing normal bone.

 

Osteosarcoma (Options A) presents with symptoms of persistent knee pain and swelling, with pain worsening at night and not relieved by NSAIDs. Biopsy shows pleomorphism, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and bizarre giant cells producing unmineralised osteoid

Osteochondroma (Options B) presents with hard mass over the right tibia, imaging showing a sessile growth, and a biopsy showing a cartilage cap

Ewing’s sarcoma (Options D) usually affects patients younger than 20 years of age and usually arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones
