questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of severe vaginal irritation and pruritus. On examination, you note a greenish-yellow, frothy discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trichomoniasis

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Trichomoniasis. This condition is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, a protozoan parasite. It is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age.

It is characterized by the following symptoms:

  • Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge
  • Vaginal irritation and pruritus
  • Painful urination
  • Pain during intercourse
  • Recurrent infections
  • Inflamed vulva
  • Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages, also known as 'strawberry cervix'

Treatment of Trichomoniasis:

  • Metronidazole 500 mg thrice daily for 1 week or a single 2 g dose.
  • Tinidazole 2 g single dose (equally effective).
  • Both partners should receive the same regimen to prevent reinfection.
  • Male partner should use a condom during intercourse until the female partner completes treatment.

 

Differential Diagnosis:

Bacterial vaginosis (Option A):

  • Typically presents with malodorous, thin, grayish-white discharge
  • Associated with overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria like Gardnerella vaginalis

Candidiasis (Option C):

  • Presents with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge
  • Associated with itching and irritation

Gonorrhea (Option D):

  • Usually presents with purulent and yellowish-green discharge
  • Not typically frothy
  • May not present with severe irritation and pruritus

questions.text: An elderly man with a chronic history of IV drug use presents with progressively increasing swelling in the groin on the right side. The swelling is non-fluctuant but pulsatile on examination. He has diminished pulses distal to the swelling on the same side. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) CT angiography followed by surgery

Explanation:

  • The pulsatile nature of the swelling, along with diminished distal pulses & history of chronic IV drug use, most likely suggests pseudoaneurysm.
  • CT angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing pseudoaneurysms, as it provides detailed imaging of the blood vessels and helps in planning surgical or endovascular repair.
  • Surgical treatment or endovascular embolisation may be required depending on the size and location of the pseudoaneurysm.

Aspect

True Aneurysm

False (Pseudoaneurysm)

Definition

Involves all three layers of the arterial wall.

Involves only a layer of fibrous tissue outside the vessel.

Wall Structure

Intima, media, and adventitia are involved.

Only fibrous tissue surrounds the breach.

Morphology

Fusiform or saccular.

Typically spherical or ovoid.

Aetiology

Atherosclerosis, genetic conditions.

Trauma, surgery, or arterial puncture.

Clinical Features

May be asymptomatic until complications arise.

Often presents with a pulsatile mass or pain.

Common Locations

Large arteries (e.g., aorta, iliac).

Peripheral arteries (e.g., femoral, popliteal).

Diagnosis

Detected by ultrasound, CT, and MRI.

Detected by ultrasound or angiography.

Management

Surgical repair or endovascular techniques.

Repair or percutaneous methods (e.g., thrombin injection).

Incorrect Options:

Oral antibiotics and observation (Option B) would not be appropriate here because there is no indication of infection (e.g., no fluctuance or signs of abscess), and this is a likely vascular issue requiring surgical intervention.

Compression stockings (Option C) are used to treat venous insufficiency or varicose veins.

Incision and drainage (Option D) are typically used for abscesses or collections of pus, & should be avoided in this case.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was presented in the psychiatric OPD with complaints of inattention at school, hitting his friends and excessive talking, poor academic performance, and inability to sit in a place for a long time. What drug is used in the management of this disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Methylphenidate

Explanation:

  • The given scenario featuring inattention, aggression, excessive talking, poor academic performance, and difficulty sitting still suggests Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), which is managed with methylphenidate.

 

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)

Aetiology

  • Genetic Factors: Runs in families, with parents or siblings more likely to have the condition (DAT1 gene and DRD4 gene).
  • Neurochemical Factors: Linked to dopamine dysfunction and noradrenergic system.
  • Neurophysiological Factors: EEG usually shows theta and beta waves in the frontal brain.
  • Neuroanatomical Factors: Decreased activity in brain areas like the prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, and basal ganglia.
  • Developmental Factors: Prenatal and perinatal factors, such as premature birth, maternal infections during pregnancy, and low birth weight, may increase the risk.
  • Psychosocial Factors: Severe abuse, neglect, or maltreatment can worsen or mimic ADHD symptoms.

Clinical features

  • Hyperactivity: Restlessness, difficulty remaining seated, inappropriate running and climbing, excessive talking, interrupting others.
  • Attention Deficit: Short attention span, distractibility, difficulty following instructions, forgetfulness, disorganisation, procrastination.
  • Impulsivity: Acting without thinking, difficulty waiting for their turn, interrupting others, blurting out answers.
  • Other: Emotional lability, explosiveness, irritability, memory and thinking defects, specific learning difficulties, speech and Hearing deficits.

Diagnosis

For an ADHD diagnosis to be confirmed, symptoms must be present in at least two different environments, such as both school and home. This ensures that the behaviour is not limited to one specific context and indicates a broader issue with attention and self-regulation.

Treatment

Pharmacotherapy

  • Stimulant Medication:
    • Methylphenidate (1st drug of choice)
    • Amphetamine (2nd drug of choice)
    • Modafinil (not FDA-approved) (Option B ruled out)
  • Non-stimulant medication
    • Atomoxetine
    • Bupropion (not FDA-approved for ADHD)

 

Psychosocial interventions

 

Atenolol (Option C) is a beta-blocker which is used in the treatment of hypertension. It has no role in the management of ADHD.

Amitriptyline (Option D) belongs to the class of tricyclic antidepressant drugs (TCA). It has no role in the management of ADHD.

questions.text: Mark the incorrect statement regarding Nipah virus:

choices.text: It is transmitted through bat urine

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) It causes hemorrhagic fever

Explanation:

  • Nipah virus belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae and genus Henipavirus.
  • Nipah virus does not primarily cause hemorrhagic fever; its main clinical manifestations are encephalitis and respiratory illness.
  • Out of the given options, this is the most incorrect statement.

 

Nipah virus

Natural reservoir

Bats

Modes of transmission

  • Direct contact with infected animals
  • Body secretion (blood, urine, faeces, seminal fluid) (Option A)
  • Consumption of contaminated food products (palm sap or fruits)

Incubation period

4-14 days

Clinical features
  • Fever, chills, headache
  • Encephalitis (M/C), acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Multiorgan failure, GIT haemorrhage (case fatality rate- 40-70%)

Incorrect Options:

It is present in India (Option C): There have been Nipah virus infection outbreaks in Kerala (2018).

It is an emerging infection (Option D): The Nipah virus is an emerging infectious agent belonging to paramyxoviridae.

questions.text: A middle-aged man came to the OPD with complaints of pain and hearing loss after trauma to the right ear. Examination revealed the presence of blood clots along with irregular perforations in the tympanic membrane. The next step in management is?

choices.text: Aspirate the clot and perform audiometric tests
Maintain dry ear with systemic analgesics

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Maintain ear dry with systemic analgesics

Explanation:

  • It indicates a probable traumatic perforation of tympanic membrane
  • Maintaining the ear dry without the use of any liquids or procedure will help the clot to fall off in any conditions of hearing loss, clots, or trauma to the tympanic membrane

 

Traumatic perforation of tympanic membrane:

Aspect

Details

Definition
  • Tear or rupture of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) due to trauma

Etiology
  • Direct trauma (e.g., cotton bud, foreign body)
  • Barotrauma (e.g., diving, blast injury, airplane pressure changes)
  • Slap/blow to the ear
  • Sudden loud noise (acoustic trauma)

Symptoms
  • Sudden ear pain
  • Hearing loss (usually conductive)
  • Tinnitus
  • Bleeding or clear discharge from ear
  • Vertigo (if inner ear involved)

Signs
  • Visible perforation on otoscopy
  • Blood/debris in the ear canal
  • Possible absent light reflex

Investigations
  • Otoscopy (main diagnostic tool)
  • Tuning fork tests (Rinne/Weber for hearing loss type)
  • Audiometry (after healing or in unclear cases)

Treatment
  • Keep ear dry (avoid water entry)
  • Most heal spontaneously within weeks
  • Avoid ear drops unless infection suspected
  • Antibiotics if contaminated or signs of infection
  • Surgical repair (myringoplasty) if not healed in 6–8 weeks

 

Incorrect Options:

Aspirate the clot and perform audiometric tests (Option A): One should not aspirate the clot because it might lead to rebleeding

Syringing (Option B): Syringing should never be performed in tympanic perforation or laceration

Gentamycin and levofloxacin ear drops (Option D): Antibiotic ear drops should no be given because ear dryness has to be maintained for the clot to fall off later

questions.text: A log dose-response curve (DRC) was plotted with isoprenaline alone and with isoprenaline in the presence of propranolol, as shown below. The graph shows that propranolol is a:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Competitive antagonist

Explanation:

  • The graph shows a parallel shift to the right, indicating that propranolol is a competitive antagonist of isoprenaline.
  • Competitive antagonists work by reversibly binding to the same receptor as the agonist (in this case, isoprenaline) but without activating the receptor. They compete with the agonist for binding sites.
  • The agonist's maximum response can still be reached but at a higher dose of the agonist.
  • In the presence of propranolol, the DRC for isoprenaline would shift to the right, indicating that higher concentrations of isoprenaline are required to achieve the same effect due to the competition for the receptor.

Partial agonist (Option A) binds to the receptor and elicits a submaximal response, even when all receptors are occupied. This is not the behaviour described for propranolol, which is a beta-blocker and not a partial agonist.

Agonist (Option B) activates a receptor to produce an effect similar to the physiological signal molecule. Propranolol is not an agonist because it does not activate the receptor. It is a beta-blocker and prevents isoprenaline from binding to and activating the beta receptors.

Non-competitive antagonist (Option D) binds to a site on the receptor that is distinct from the agonist binding site and reduces the maximum response even if the agonist concentration is increased. In contrast, a competitive antagonist can be displaced by increasing the concentration of the agonist.

questions.text: The biological method for Mosquito Larva control is done by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Gambusia fish

Explanation:

  • Gambusia fish are voracious feeders and consume mosquito larvae, thus helping to reduce the mosquito population in water bodies where they are introduced. They are particularly effective in controlling mosquito larvae in stagnant or slow-moving water bodies like ponds, ditches, and water tanks.
  • This method of biological control is environmentally friendly and sustainable. Additionally, Gambusia fish are easy to rear and maintain, making them a practical and cost-effective solution for mosquito larva control in certain habitats.

Anti-larval measures against mosquito larvae:

Environmental measures

Chemical control

Biological control

Yield permanent results and source reduction.

 

E.g.

 

  • Filling drains and ditches.
  • Levelling of ground.
  • Proper drainage of breeding areas.
  • Intermittent irrigation.
  • Changing water alkalinity.

Using larvicides

 

E.g.

 

1. Physical:

  • MLO (Mosquito larvicidal oil): 200L/hectare

2. Chemical:

  • Paris green
  • Temephos (Abate): 200L/hectare

3. IGR (insect growth regulators):

  • Inhibit chitin formation, moulding and adult maturation.
  • Pyriproxyfen and Diflubenzuron

Larvivorous Fishes:

 

1. Gambusia and Poecilia fish

2. Bacillus thuringiensis (used in polluted waters)

3. Toxorhynchites splendens

(predator mosquito for Aedes and Anopheles)

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are necessary for purine ring formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glycine, Aspartate, Glutamine

Explanation

Purine ring formation requires three amino acids - Glycine, Aspartate, Glutamine and the cofactor N10-formyl tetrahydrofolate (N10- formyl THF) for purine ring formation.

(Option B) (Option A, C and D ruled out)

  • The sources of each atom in a purine were found by feeding isotopic precursors of uric acid to pigeons.
    • The C-2 atom is from formyl THF
    • The C-8 atom is from N5N10 methenyl THF
    • The C-6 atom is from respiratory CO2.
    • N1 is from aspartate
    • N3 and N9 are from Glutamine
    • C4, C5 and N7 are from Glycine

questions.text: Identify the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

Explanation:

  • It has two valves-one connected to the trachea and other valve to esophagus
  • Provox and Blom singer are some of its types.

 

Incorrect Options:

Montgomery tube (Option A): This instrument works like a stent to keep the lumen patent whenever there is subglottic and tracheal resection done.

BAHA (Option C): Bone anchored hearing aid is used for patient with hearing loss especially conductive hearing loss

PORP prosthesis (Option D): This is used in ossicular chain reconstruction/Ossiculoplasty

questions.text: What are the potential effects of folic acid deficiency during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Neural tube defects

Explanation:

  • Adequate folic acid levels are crucial for the proper closure of the neural tube during early fetal development. If a pregnant woman does not have enough folic acid, it can lead to neural tube defects.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not caused by folic acid deficiency during pregnancy.

questions.text: Mid-year population is the denominator in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) CDR

Explanation:

  • The crude death rate (CDR) is a demographic indicator that measures the number of deaths in a population per 1,000 individuals per year.

  • It is calculated by dividing the total number of deaths in a given period by the mid-year population and multiplying by 1,000.

CDR = (Number of deaths / Mid-year population) x 1000

  • Therefore, the mid-year population serves as the denominator in calculating the crude death rate. This rate provides a broad overview of mortality within a population, irrespective of age or other factors.

Incorrect Options:

CFR (Option B):

  • The case fatality rate (CFR) is a measure of the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a particular disease or condition who die from that disease or condition within a specified time period.

  • It is calculated by dividing the number of deaths from the disease by the number of diagnosed cases and multiplying by 100 to get a percentage.

  • CFR is commonly used in epidemiology and public health to assess the severity of a disease outbreak or epidemic.

MMR (Option C):

  • The maternal mortality rate (MMR) is a measure of the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.

  • It reflects the risk associated with childbirth and pregnancy-related complications.

  • MMR is an important indicator of maternal health and healthcare system performance, especially in developing countries where maternal mortality rates tend to be higher.

NMR (Option D):

  • The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) is a measure of the number of deaths among newborns (within the first 28 days of life) per 1,000 live births.

  • It specifically focuses on mortality during the neonatal period, which is critical for assessing the quality of maternal and newborn healthcare services.

  • NMR is an essential indicator for monitoring progress in reducing infant mortality and improving newborn health outcomes.

questions.text: When are the three doses of fIPV ideally given as per the National Immunization Schedule?

choices.text: 3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months
At 10 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months
At 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 18 completed months
3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 18 completed months

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 3 doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 completed months

Explanation:

  • IPV ( Inactivated Polio vaccine) is administered by intramuscular or fractional dose by intradermal injection
  • Schedule of fIPV (fractional IPV): 6 and 14 weeks; 0.1 ml ID Right upper arm.
    fIPV: 1/5th of the full dose.
  • From 1 January 2023, the third dose of IPV is introduced into the NIS, which is administered at 9 completed months of age: 0.1 ml ID Left upper arm (as the MR vaccine is administered in the right upper arm).

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following is a mitochondrial matrix enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Citrate synthase

Explanation

Citrate synthase is a key enzyme of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle and is located in the mitochondrial matrix. It catalyzes the condensation of oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA to form citrate.

Monoamine oxidase (Option B): Monoamine oxidase is an enzyme located in the outer mitochondrial membrane and is involved in the oxidative deamination of monoamines, such as serotonin and dopamine.

ATP synthase (Option C): ATP synthase is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane and extends into the matrix. While it has a role in the matrix during ATP production, it is not classified as a matrix enzyme.

Catalase (Option D): Catalase is an enzyme located in peroxisomes, not mitochondria. It catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen.

questions.text: Check-ups conducted for children aged 9-18 years under Rashtriya Bal Swasthya karyakram is done for every?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Semi-annually

Explanation:

  • Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram was launched in 2013.
  • It relies on early childhood and interventional services.
  • Children between 6-18 years are screened at government schools by a mobile health team at least 2 times a year.

RBSK Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram:

RBSK
  • Launched in 2013.
  • Relies on early childhood screening and interventional services.

Age group
  • 0-6 years- urban or rural slums
  • 6-18 years- government school-going children

Screening

Secondary level of prevention

Screening done for 4Ds:

  • Diseases
  • Defects
  • Deficiencies
  • Developmental delays

Screened by

Mobile teams and this includes:

  • Medical officers
  • Ayush officers
  • Pharmacists
  • Lab technicians

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect

questions.text: A young male patient presents with sudden onset chest pain for one hour with ECG showing STE in lead 2,3 and aVF. Which is the best treatment for this case of inferior wall MI in a multispecialty hospital?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Primary angioplasty

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations (sudden onset chest pain) with characteristic ECG findings (ST elevation in lead 2,3 and aVF) indicate an acute inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Primary angioplasty, also known as Primary Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI), is the gold standard treatment for STEMI when performed at a capable facility within 120 minutes of first medical contact.

  • Immediate Goals:
    • Control cardiac discomfort.
    • Rapidly identify patients for reperfusion therapy.
    • Proper triage of lower-risk patients.
    • Avoid inappropriate discharge of STEMI patients.
  • Overall Aim: Initiate percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) within 120 minutes of first medical contact, including transfer to a PCI-capable facility if necessary.

 

Alteplase (Option A): Alteplase, a tissue plasminogen activator, is only preferred in non-PCI-capable hospitals, where patients are further to be transferred to a PCI capable hospital. In a multispecialty hospital with PCI capabilities, primary angioplasty offers better outcomes with lower bleeding risk.

Streptokinase (Option B): Streptokinase is no longer the treatment of choice according to current guidelines due to its risk of anaphylaxis and inferior outcomes compared to primary PCI.

Dabigatran (Option D): Dabigatran is an anticoagulant and is not indicated for the treatment of STEMI. While anticoagulation is part of STEMI management, direct oral anticoagulants like dabigatran are not the primary treatment strategy in acute STEMI.

PIM050

questions.text: What is the rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HMG-CoA reductase

Explanation

  • The principal regulatory step in the cholesterol synthesis pathway: HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate
  • It is catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase

Regulation of HMG-CoA reductase:

Regulation Method

Mechanism

Sufficient Cholesterol

Suppresses transcription of HMG CoA reductase gene

Low Dietary Cholesterol

Increases transcription of HMG CoA reductase gene

AMP-activated Kinase

Phosphorylates HMG CoA reductase inactivating it

Protein Phosphatase 1

Dephosphorylates HMG CoA reductase activating it

Insulin and Thyroxine

Increase activity of HMG CoA reductase

Cortisol and Glucagon

Decrease activity of HMG CoA reductase

Statins (e.g., Lovastatin)

Competitive inhibition of HMG CoA reductase

7-alpha hydroxylase (Option B): This enzyme is the rate-limiting step in bile acid synthesis, not cholesterol synthesis.

Carnitine acyltransferase 1 (Option C): This enzyme is the rate-limiting enzyme in fatty acid oxidation, facilitating the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria.


Carnitine acyltransferase 2 (Option D): This enzyme is involved in fatty acid oxidation but is not the rate-limiting step. It helps regenerate free carnitine in the mitochondrial matrix.

questions.text: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. His viscera was preserved during autopsy. Which of the following can be detected in his visceral organs even on non-consumption before his death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Alcohol

Explanation:

In cases where the body is preserved, ethanol can be detected in the viscera due to the fermentation of body fluids and tissues. This post-mortem production of alcohol can make its detection possible even if the person did not consume alcohol before death.

Morphine (Options A), Aconite (Option B), and Arsenic (Option C) can only be detected if they were consumed by the person

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug for the treatment of postmenopausal breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Anastrozole

Explanation:

  • Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor and is a standard treatment for postmenopausal breast cancer, particularly in hormone receptor-positive (HR-positive) breast cancer.
  • It works by inhibiting the enzyme aromatase, which converts androgens to estrogens.
  • Lower estrogen levels are effective in slowing or stopping the growth of estrogen-dependent breast cancer cells.

Methotrexate (Option A) is a chemotherapy agent and immunosuppressant which is only used as part of a combination chemotherapy regimen including Cyclophosphamide and 5-Fluorouracil to treat early-stage breast cancer, especially where anthracyclines are contraindicated.

Raloxifene (Option B) is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It is FDA-approved for managing both the prevention and treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. It is not considered the preferred treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

Tamoxifen (Option C) is also a SERM and is an effective treatment for pre-menopausal women. It works by blocking estrogen receptors on breast cancer cells, which can slow or stop the growth of tumors that require estrogen to grow.

questions.text: Which bones are cut/removed during external Dacryocystorhinostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lacrimal

Explanation:

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a surgical procedure performed to treat nasolacrimal duct obstruction, which causes epiphora due to impaired tear drainage. The surgery involves creating a new drainage pathway for tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity.

Indications for DCR:

  • Chronic dacryocystitis (infection of the lacrimal sac)
  • Obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct (either congenital or acquired, e.g., from trauma or aging)
  • Recurrent epiphora (despite conservative treatments)

Types of DCR:

  1. External DCR (Traditional):
    • Involves making an incision on the skin near the medial canthus of the eye .
    • The lacrimal bone (Mostly) and a portion of the maxillary bone are removed to create an opening between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity.
    • A stent is often placed to keep the passage open until healing is complete.
  2. Endoscopic DCR (Minimally invasive):
    • No external incision is made.
    • An endoscope is inserted through the nasal cavity to create a passage between the lacrimal sac and nasal cavity.
    • This approach is preferred for cosmetic reasons and for patients who may have anatomical difficulties with external incisions.

Postoperative Care:

  • Antibiotics are prescribed to prevent infection.
  • Stent removal (if placed) occurs after 6–8 weeks.
  • Nasal saline irrigation may be recommended to keep the new drainage pathway clear.

Complications:

  • Infection
  • Stenosis (narrowing) of the new drainage passage
  • Persistent epiphora or failure of the procedure

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is seen in rickets?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Vitamin D

Explanation:

  • Vitamin D deficiency is associated with Rickets

 

Feature

Calcipenic Rickets

Cause

Inadequate calcium intake (often vitamin D deficiency)

Calcium Status

Low calcium absorption leads to hypocalcemia

Phosphate Status

Hypophosphatemia due to a decrease in tubular phosphate resorption.

Pathophysiological Mechanism

Activation of the parathyroid–bone axis for calcium preservation

Associated Conditions

Primarily linked to vitamin D deficiency

Effect on Growth Plate

Reduced apoptosis of hypertrophic chondrocytes due to hypophosphatemia

 

Options A, B & C: Vitamin A, Vitamin B & Vitamin C are not associated with Rickets.

questions.text: What is the tumour marker for a carcinoid tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 5-HIAA

Explanation:

  • The tumour marker for a Carcinoid Tumor is 5-HIAA (5-hydroxy indole acetic acid).
  • Carcinoids are derived from Argentaffin cells that secrete serotonin.
  • It is commonly caused by neuroendocrine tumours of the midgut that metastasise to the liver.
  • It is also seen with ovarian tumours or bronchial carcinoids. They secrete mediators like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), kallikrein, bradykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins.
  • Clinical features:
    • Diarrhea and abdominal cramping
    • Flushing and pruritus due to histamine
    • Wheezing and dyspnea due to bronchospasm
    • Pellagra (diarrhoea, dermatitis, dementia)
    • Carcinoid heart disease: Tricuspid regurgitation leading to right heart failure
  • Diagnosis:
    • Elevated twenty-four-hour urine for 5-HIAA.
    • Elevated serum serotonin.
    • Elevated serum chromogranin A.
    • Octreoscan for localising the source.

Tumor marker

Associated conditions

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Option D ruled out)

 
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Yolk sac tumour (endodermal sinus tumour)
  • Nonseminomatous germ cell tumour of testis
  • ↑ AFP: abdominal wall defects, neural tube defects
  • ↓ AFP: associated with trisomy 21, 18, and 13

β-HCG (Option A ruled out)

 
  • Nonseminomatous testicular germ cell tumours (choriocarcinoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, mixed germ cell tumour, seminoma)
  • Ovarian cancer: choriocarcinoma (gestational trophoblastic disease)

Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Colorectal cancer
  • Pancreatic cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Lung cancer (especially in non-small cell cancers)
  • Gastric cancer

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
  • Prostate cancer
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Prostatitis

Calcitonin (Option B ruled out)
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (both sporadic and associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2)

Alkaline phosphatase
  • Metastases to bone or liver
  • Paget disease of the bone

Placental alkaline phosphatase
  • Seminoma

Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ovarian cancer (dysgerminoma)
  • Testicular germ cell tumours (both seminoma and nonseminoma)
  • Lymphomas
  • Ewing's sarcoma

Neuron specific enolase (NSE)
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Neuroblastoma

CA 19–9

  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Colon cancer
  • Cholangiocarcinoma

CA 15–3 and CA 27–29
  • Breast cancer

CA 125

  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Other gynecologic malignancies

S-100 protein (S100A) and (S100B)
  • Malignant melanoma

SMRP
  • Mesothelioma

questions.text: What is the next step in the management of a suspected tubal pregnancy with inconclusive transvaginal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serum beta hCG levels

Explanation:

Serial serum beta hCG monitoring is the appropriate next step when transvaginal ultrasound is inconclusive in suspected tubal pregnancy.

  • Serial beta hCG measurements are the first choice investigation for suspected ectopic pregnancy when ultrasound is inconclusive.
  • Normal rise in early viable pregnancy shows doubling of beta-hCG levels over 48 hours
  • Discriminatory zone (1500-2000 mIU/mL) represents the beta hCG level at which a gestational sac should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound
  • Abnormal rise or plateau suggests potential ectopic pregnancy and guides further management

Diagnostic Modality

Findings for Unruptured Ectopic Pregnancy

Beta hCG Levels
  • Failure to double the value of β-hCG in 48 hours
  • Lower concentration of β-hCG than expected for gestational age

Transvaginal Sonography (TVS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac within the uterine cavity when β-hCG ≥ 1500 IU/L.
  • Adnexal Mass: An adnexal mass clearly separate from the ovary (Blob sign).
  • Ring-of-Fire Pattern: Increased blood flow around the ectopic mass on Color Doppler.
  • Presence of pseudo gestational sac.
  • Free fluid in the Pouch of Douglas

Transabdominal Sonography (TAS)
  • Absence of Intrauterine Pregnancy: No gestational sac when β-hCG ≥ 6,000 IU/L
  • Other features: May be visible but less sensitive than TVS for smaller masses

 

Methotrexate administration (Option B): Medical management with methotrexate is inappropriate without definitively diagnosing an ectopic pregnancy and ensuring specific selection criteria are met. Methotrexate is contraindicated if there is any possibility of a viable intrauterine pregnancy.

Laparotomy (Option C): Emergency laparotomy is reserved for patients with suspected ectopic pregnancy who are hemodynamically unstable or show signs of acute abdomen. This patient is stable and requires definitive diagnosis before any surgical intervention.

Diagnostic laparoscopy (Option D): While laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic tool for ectopic pregnancy, it is too invasive as an initial diagnostic step when the patient is stable and diagnosis is unclear. Less invasive options like serial beta hCG monitoring should be exhausted first.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female presented with Schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drugs causes the least weight gain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ziprasidone

Explanation:

  • Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic that is known for having a relatively low risk of causing weight gain compared to other antipsychotics.
  • It has a lower affinity for H1 histamine receptors (which are involved in appetite stimulation) and a high affinity for 5-HT2C receptors.
  • Ziprasidone is often preferred in patients who are concerned about weight gain or who are already overweight or obese.

Chlorpromazine (Option A) is a typical antipsychotic that blocks dopamine D2 receptors to alleviate psychotic symptoms. It carries a risk for metabolic side effects like weight gain, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

Clozapine (Option B) is an atypical antipsychotic that primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C). Weight gain is a common side effect of Clozapine.

Olanzapine (Option C) is an atypical antipsychotic that is associated with weight gain and other metabolic side effects.

questions.text: Which tuberculosis drug causes impairment of color vision and optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ethambutol

Explanation:

Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that causes retrobulbar neuritis, decreased visual acuity and colour blindness.

 

Ethambutol

MOA

Inhibits arabinosyl transferases involved in arabinogalactan synthesis, thereby interfering with mycolic acid synthesis in cell wall

Mechanism of resistance

Mutation of embAB genes, which encodes the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, reducing its affinity for ethambutol

Uses

In the treatment of

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC)
  • Mycobacterium kansasii

Side effects
  • Painless loss of vision
    • Field defects due to retrobulbar neuritis (Option C)
    • Loss of visual acuity
    • Red-green colour blindness
  • Nausea, rashes, fever

Option A, C and D does not cause visual impairment.

questions.text: A 70 year old male patient presents to the OPD with multiple, recurrent fainting episodes. An ECG was taken and it shows P waves at a rate of 75 bpm and qrs complexes at a rate of 35 bpm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stokes adams syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Stokes Adams syndrome, characterized by complete heart block with recurrent syncope. The ECG findings show P waves at 75 bpm with QRS complexes at 35 bpm, demonstrating AV dissociation typical of complete heart block or IIIrd degree heart block.
  • This indicates a complete interruption of electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles, leading to independent atrial and ventricular rhythms.

Third-degree atrioventricular block / Stokes-Adams Syndrome

Definition

Complete failure of conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in independent beating (AV dissociation).

Ventricular Activity

Maintained by an escape rhythm from:

  • The AV node or bundle of His (narrow QRS complexes).
  • Distal Purkinje tissues (broad QRS complexes).

ECG Findings
  • Prolonged PR interval
  • Broad QRS complex
  • Number of P waves will not be equal to the number of R waves
  • P-R interval (atrial rate) will not match the R-R interval (ventricular rate)

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent syncope or 'Stokes–Adams' attacks- sudden loss of consciousness and collapse.
  • Brief anoxic seizure.
  • Pallor and a death-like appearance during the attack; characteristic flush upon recovery.
  • Rapid recovery distinguishes it from epilepsy.

Management
  • Depends on clinical circumstances.
  • Transient AV block in acute inferior myocardial infarction- no treatment if the patient remains stable.
  • Symptomatic third-degree AV block- intravenous atropine or intravenous isoprenaline to maintain circulation until temporary pacing is inserted.
  • Permanent pacemaker.

 

Mobitz type II heart block (Option A) presents with intermittent failure of AV conduction with normal PR intervals 200ms. Unlike complete heart block, some P waves still conduct to the ventricles, and the pattern is not consistent with the current ECG findings.

First degree heart block (Option C) shows prolonged PR interval >200ms with 1:1 AV conduction. This is typically asymptomatic and would not cause the presenting symptoms of recurrent syncope.

Wolf parkinson white syndrome (Option D) presents with a short PR interval <120ms and delta waves. This represents pre-excitation through an accessory pathway and does not cause the AV dissociation seen in this case.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the abdomen for 1.5 years. She has a history of midline surgery. On examination, the swelling is 4 cm and is reducible with a palpable cough impulse. She is planning to undergo fascial closure with mesh repair. What is the most likely location of the mesh shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Onlay

Explanation:

  • This patient most likely has an incisional hernia, which is a common complication following midline surgery, characterised by a bulge or swelling at the site of a previous incision.
  • The treatment often involves fascial closure with mesh repair to reinforce the weakened abdominal wall.
  • The given image shows Onlay mesh repair technique.

Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques:

Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

 

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

 

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from the posterior rectus sheath; mesh is placed in this space, and the peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: A patient who received a supraclavicular brachial plexus block with 0.5% bupivacaine develops hypotension and arrhythmias. What is the first-line treatment for this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) 20% intralipid infusion

Explanation: This is a case of Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) caused by bupivacaine as seen by the cardiac side effects (hypotension and arryhthmia). Treatment of choice is 20% intralipid infusion.

Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST):

Clinical Features

CNS effects:

  • Early and less severe.
  • First symptom: circumoral paraesthesia
  • First sign: nystagmus
  • At low plasma concentration: mild sensory disturbances.
  • Increased concentration: CNS excitation, seizure activity.
  • Higher concentration: CNS depression, coma, respiratory depression, arrest.

Cardiac effects:

  • Usually late but severe form of toxicity, may lead to death.
  • Hypotension, dysrhythmias, myocardial depression.
  • Potent agents (bupivacaine, ropivacaine, levobupivacaine) linked to cardiovascular collapse, heart block.

Safety profile

Bupivacaine has more risk to cause LAST than Lidocaine

Most potent highly lipid soluble drugs are more likely to cause

Prevention
  • Risk recognition and dose reduction.
  • Careful aspiration before injection.
  • Incremental administration (3-5 mL) with continuous heart rate monitoring.
  • Use ultrasonographic guidance to confirm anesthetic deposit.
  • Use a vasoactive agent like epinephrine to reduce systemic absorption and serve as an intravascular indicator.

Treatment
  • Recognize LAST (Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity) early and call for help.
  • Airway management: Secure airway, ventilate with 100% oxygen.
  • Administer 20% Lipid Emulsion:
    • Bolus: 12 mL/kg over 2-3 min.
    • Infusion: at 0.25 mL/kg/min-0.5ml/kg/min for 15-20 mins
    • Maximum initial dose: 12 ml/kg
  • Administration of antiepileptics: for seizure control, benzodiazepines such as Lorazepam is preferred.
  • Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: if necessary, monitor the patient at least for initial 2-6 hours following resuscitation.

Incorrect Options:

Invasive ventilation and Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (Option A and D): This is indicated only if there is a cardiac arrest. Since the question stem indicates hypotension and arrhythmia, this is not the correct answer.

Sodium bicarbonate (Option C): Lipid emulsion therapy is preferred over sodium bicarbonate for bupivacaine toxicity because it directly binds and sequesters bupivacaine, reducing its concentration and toxic effects on the heart and brain. Sodium bicarbonate can help correct metabolic acidosis, but it doesn’t target bupivacaine toxicity directly and is less effective in severe cases. Lipid emulsion therapy is considered the most effective treatment for life-threatening toxicity.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of renal calculi presents with bone pain and abdominal cramps. X-ray shows subperiosteal resorption of the 2nd and 3rd metacarpals and phalanges. Serum calcium and PTH are raised, and phosphate levels are decreased. Which of the following investigations will help localise the pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 99Tc radiolabelled sestamibi scan

Explanation:

  • This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma.
  • The characteristic findings of subperiosteal resorption on X-ray, along with elevated calcium and PTH levels and low phosphate, point towards this diagnosis.
  • To localise the pathology (typically a parathyroid adenoma), the most appropriate imaging test is a 99Tc radiolabelled sestamibi scan.

Sestamibi scan is a type of nuclear medicine-based study that is most accurate for parathyroid lesion localisation.

  • It is safe and reproducible.
  • It has a sensitivity and specificity similar to ultrasound but may detect glands in ectopic positions better.
  • Sestamibi accumulates in the mitochondria, and henc,e the rates at which it washes out differ as per the number of mitochondria in different tissues.
  • Parathyroid adenoma is rich in oxyphilic cells with a high concentration of mitochondria and, hence has a lower washout than the thyroid gland.
  • False positives are rare, and the sensitivity and specificity are 79% and 90,% respectively.
  • Addition of a thyroid specific radioactive tracer eliminates the chance of false positives.

 

 

Other investigations: Parathyroid angiography and venous sampling for parathyroid hormone.

Biochemical analysis is always to be done.

Incorrect Options:

Ultrasonography (Option C):

  • Parathyroid adenoma is identified as an oval/ elongated, bi or multiloculated hypoechoic structure.
  • Advantage: Can identify and facilitate biopsy of any concomitant thyroid pathology.
  • Disadvantage: Adenomas in retro-oesophageal, retrosternal, or retro-tracheal areas can be missed.

CT (Option D):

  • Rapid uptake and washout allow hyperfunctioning glands to be differentiated from lymph nodes that demonstrate a progressive enhancement pattern.
  • Disadvantage: Higher radiation dose than traditional imaging. Hence, it is not preferred.

MRI (Option B):

  • It is not commonly used, but it is helpful for preoperative cases or mediastinal adenomas.
  • It has poor resolution for small glands/adenomas <5 mm, and it is difficult to localise superior glands.

Biochemical tests: (Hyperparathyroidism)

Serum calcium levels

High

Intact PTH

Low or inappropriately high

Serum phosphate

Low

24-hour urinary calcium

High

Chloride to phosphate ratio

High

1,25- hydroxy Vitamin D

Normal or raised

questions.text: A patient fell from a train onto the railway track and injured both his legs severely. He was urgently taken to the hospital, and the following procedure was performed (image shown below). What is the rationale for performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Life-saving procedure

Explanation:

  • In cases of severe trauma, such as being run over or falling on railway tracks, injuries can be so extensive that amputation is necessary to prevent massive blood loss, gangrene, or infection, which can lead to death. The decision for a bilateral below-knee amputation is usually made as a life-saving measure when there is irreversible damage to the legs.

Indications for Amputation:

  • Dead Limb: Gangrene
  • Deadly Limb
    • Wet gangrene
    • Spreading cellulitis
    • Arteriovenous fistula
    • Malignancy (e.g., sarcoma)
  • Dead loss of limb:
    • Severe rest pain due to irreversible critical leg ischemia
    • Paralysis
    • Severe contracture
    • Trauma (irreparable damage)

Local Amputation:

  • For small-vessel disease (e.g., diabetes): Gangrene of toes may require local amputation. If the metatarsophalangeal joint is involved, ray excision may be necessary.

Major Amputation:

  • Below-knee Amputation: Preserves knee joint, offering better prosthetic use.
  • Above-knee Amputation: For poor circulation or non-mobilizing patients.
  • Knee Disarticulation: Preserves femur and patella for better prosthetic function.

Post-operative care:

  • Pain Management: Regular opiate use.
  • Limb Care: Prevent pressure ulcers on the remaining limb.
  • Exercise: Prevent deformities, build strength, and improve mobility.

Complications:

  • Early: Hemorrhage, infection, gas gangrene, and wound dehiscence.
  • Late: Phantom limb pain, stump ulceration, DVT, and pulmonary embolism

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type II Tyrosinemia

Explanation

  • Type II tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of tyrosine transaminase (also known as tyrosine aminotransferase), which leads to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.
  • This condition primarily affects the eyes, skin, and nervous system, with symptoms including corneal ulcers and intellectual disability.

Disorders of Tyrosine Metabolism

Disorder

Deficiency Enzyme

Key Clinical Features

Tyrosinemia type I

(Option A ruled out)

Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase
  • Jaundice, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, HCC, liver cirrhosis
  • Often presents with Fanconi syndrome and renal failure
  • Elevated tyrosine and succinylacetone (pathognomic)

Tyrosinemia type II

(Option B)

Tyrosine aminotransferase
  • Painful corneal erosions, palmoplantar hyperkeratosis
  • Also known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia
  • Elevated tyrosine

Tyrosinemia type III

(Option D ruled out)

p-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase
  • Recurrent seizures, intermittent ataxia
  • Elevated tyrosine and p-hydroxyphenylpyruvate

Alkaptonuria (Black urine disease)

(Option C ruled out)

Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase
  • Dark urine, ochronosis, arthritis
  • Black or brown pigmentation of sclera (Osler’s sign) and ear cartilage
  • Elevated homogentisic acid

questions.text: Which of the following regulates body temperature?

Correct Answer: A) Hypothalamus

Explanation:

The hypothalamus is the part of the brain that regulates body temperature, acting as the body's thermostat​

Limbic System (Option D): is associated with emotions, memory, and arousal (or stimulation). It includes structures like the hippocampus and amygdala, which are crucial for emotional responses and memory formation
