questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in 3rd trimester presents to the emergency department after experiencing a fainting episode while lying down. She reports feeling better once she sits up. What is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IVC compression

Explanation:

  • IVC compression causes supine hypotension syndrome
  • During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava when the patient is in supine position
  • This results in opening up of the collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygos veins
  • In some cases (10%), when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed

Clinical Features:

  • Results in production of hypotension, tachycardia and syncope
  • The normal BP is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position (left → right)

Incorrect Options:

SVC compression (Option B): Compression of the superior vena cava can cause symptoms like facial swelling and jugular venous distension, but it is not typically associated with fainting episodes when lying down.

Hypotension (Option C):

  • Hypotension can occur due to IVC compression but it is not the underlying cause of positional syncope seen in the patient.

Motion sickness (Option D):

  • Motion sickness is usually accompanied by nausea and vomiting. It is triggered by motion but not associated with positional changes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic patient presents to the ER with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Blood investigations reveal increased serum amylase and lipase levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of alcohol consumption, along with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and significantly elevated serum amylase and lipase levels, points strongly toward acute pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis:

  • Clinical features:
    • Pain (severe, constant, and often resistant to common analgesics).
    • In about 50% of patients, the pain radiates to the back, and some patients may find relief by sitting or leaning forward.
    • Nausea and vomiting are usually prominent, and retching may persist even with nasogastric aspiration.
  • Examination findings:
    • Patient's condition: well to severely ill with signs of shock and toxicity.
    • Tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension are commonly observed.
    • Mild icterus may suggest biliary obstruction (in gallstone pancreatitis).
    • SIRS may be present
    • Bluish discolouration (Grey Turner’s sign or Cullen’s sign).
    • Abdominal distension due to ileus or ascites is common, and muscle guarding is often present.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum amylase level > 3x the normal value is strongly indicative.
    • Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than amylase.
    • CECT scan is the gold standard for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Mild cases may be managed with IV fluids, analgesics, and antiemetics.
    • Nil per os (NPO) is typically advised initially to avoid stimulating the pancreas.
    • Antibiotics are not generally indicated unless there is suspicion of infection
  • Management of severe cases:
    • Admit to intensive care or a high-dependency unit for close monitoring.
    • Aggressive fluid resuscitation is critical, guided by vital signs, urine output, and central venous pressure.
    • Oxygen supplementation and serial blood gas analysis.
    • If nutritional support is necessary, enteral feeding via nasogastric tube is preferred over parenteral nutrition.
  • Management of specific complications:
    • Antibiotics may be indicated if cholangitis or other infections are suspected. Prophylactic antibiotics should not exceed 14 days.
    • If gallstone pancreatitis is suspected and there is biliary obstruction, ERCP should be performed within 72 hours.
  • Complications:
    • Shock, arrhythmias, ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), renal failure, and DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation).
    • Metabolic derangements like hypocalcemia, hyperglycemia, and hyperlipidemia may occur.
    • Peripancreatic fluid collection, pancreatic abscess, pseudocyst, and pancreatic necrosis.
    • Pleural effusion, pancreatic ascites, and pancreatic haemorrhage (pseudoaneurysm) are also common.

Incorrect Options:

Peptic ulcer disease (Option A) typically presents with epigastric pain, but it doesn't radiate to the back & does not cause elevated amylase and lipase levels.

Acute cholecystitis (Option C) presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, often with fever and nausea, but it is not typically associated with marked increases in amylase and lipase. This condition would usually show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin.

Pyogenic liver abscess (Option D) can present with fever and abdominal pain, but it does not typically cause significant increases in amylase and lipase. This condition would be more likely to show abnormal liver function tests and may be associated with other findings like fever or jaundice.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dermatomyositis

Explanation:

The given image shows a heliotrope rash, which is a characteristic feature of Dermatomyositis.

 

Clinical Features of Dermatomyositis

 

  • Weakness: Symmetric, proximal greater than distal.
  • Rash: Characteristic rashes include:
    • Heliotrope rash: Erythematous eyelid discolouration with periorbital edema.
    • Gottron sign: Erythematous rash over extensor surfaces (knuckles, elbows, knees, ankles).
    • Gottron papules: Raised erythematous rash over knuckles.
    • V-sign: Rash on sun-exposed anterior neck and chest.
    • Shawl sign: Rash over the back of the neck and shoulders.
    • Nail bed telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries at nail beds.
    • Subcutaneous calcium deposits.
  • Weakness and rash can appear together or be separated by months.
  • Some patients may present with only a rash (amyopathic DM), while others may show mainly weakness.
  • Additional Symptoms: Myalgias, arthralgias, dysphagia, and dysarthria.
  • Skin symptoms significantly affect overall life quality; pruritus can be debilitating.
  • Pulmonary Issues: Dyspnea from ventilatory muscle weakness or intrinsic lung problems (interstitial lung disease, bronchopneumonia, alveolitis).
  • Malignancy Risk: Higher risk (~15%) in adult-onset cases within the first 2–3 years.

 

Heliotrope rash

Gottron’s Papules

 

Shawl sign

V Sign

Polymyositis (Option A): Muscle involvement similar to dermatomyositis but lacks skin manifestations.

Inclusion body myositis (Option C):

  • Does not present with a heliotrope rash.
  • The feature distinguishing inclusion body myosistis from dermatomyositis and polymyositis is the lack of responsiveness to immunosuppressive treatment.

Discoid lupus erythematosus (Option D):

  • Carpet track or Tin tack sign, also called Cat's tongue is characteristic of DLE.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with chronic pancreatitis undergoes a Puestow procedure. What is the most preferred route for supplementary nutrition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition)

Explanation:

  • TPN is typically indicated when enteral feeding via the gastrointestinal tract is not possible or not well tolerated.
  • After a Puestow procedure, especially if there are concerns about pancreatic insufficiency, altered gut anatomy, or complications like fistulas.

Post-operative care in patients with chronic pancreatitis following a Puestow procedure:

  • Nutrition: Provide nutrition via TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) or jejunostomy feeding, depending on the patient's condition and tolerance.
  • Fluid and electrolyte management: Ensure careful monitoring and correction of fluid and electrolyte balance.
  • Sepsis prevention and control: Take proactive measures to prevent infections and monitor for signs of sepsis regularly.
  • Octreotide use: Administer octreotide during the surgery and continue at regular intervals or as a slow infusion postoperatively for up to 5 days to help reduce pancreatic secretion and minimize complications.

TPN Formulations:

3 in 1 formulation

2 in 1 formulation

Solutions with lipids (Option C)

Solutions without lipids

60/20/20

  • 60% by dextrose
  • 20% by amino acids
  • 20% by fat.

75/25

  • 75% by dextrose
  • 25% by amino acids
  • No lipids used

Fiber is absent in both formulations

 

Complications of Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN):

Line Insertion Complications
  • Pneumothorax (most dangerous)
  • Misplacement of catheter

Line-Related Complications
  • Sepsis (most common)
  • Thrombosis (more common with long-term catheter use)
  • Electrolyte imbalances (e.g., refeeding syndrome)

Metabolic Complications
  • Blood sugar derangements (hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia)
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Metabolic bone disease
  • Vitamin deficiencies

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist complaining of curd-like white vaginal discharge. Upon examination, the physician observes that when attempting to remove the discharge, petechiae are seen. What condition is most likely causing these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Candidiasis

Explanation:

Candidiasis:

  • A fungal infection caused by Candida albicans
  • Characteristic presentation includes:
    • Curd-like white discharge
    • Plaque on the vaginal wall that causes petechiae when removed
    • Out of proportion pruritus and splash dysuria are common symptoms

 

Differential Diagnosis:

Trichomoniasis (Option B):

  • Presents with greenish-yellow, frothy discharge
  • Pruritus present
  • Does not cause petechiae on removal of discharge

Gardnella vaginalis (Option C):

  • Presents with thin creamy white discharge with fishy odour
  • No associated petechiae on examination

Gonorrhea (Option D):

  • Presents with purulent yellow-green vaginal discharge
  • No characteristic petechiae formation

questions.text: A woman who has done strenuous exercise complains of involuntary urine voiding during work out. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stress incontinence

Explanation:

Definition and Mechanism:

  • Stress incontinence is defined as an involuntary escape of urine from the external urinary meatus due to a sudden rise in IAP
  • It occurs due to the straightening of the angle between the urethra and bladder to 110° (normal angle is 85°)
  • Characterized by involuntary urine loss during physical exertion, coughing, or sneezing

Clinical Features:

  • Only small amounts of urine leak
  • Patient is aware of the leakage
  • Specifically occurs during effort or physical activities

 

Urge incontinence (Option A):

  • Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency
  • Sudden, compelling desire to void that is difficult to defer
  • Not related to physical activity

Neurogenic incontinence (Option C):

  • Occurs due to complete disruption of motor and sensory nervous system control over the bladder
  • Not related to physical exertion

Mixed urinary incontinence (Option D):

  • Combination of urge and stress incontinence
  • Involves both urgency and physical exertion/sneezing/coughing
  • Not purely exercise-induced

questions.text: Which of the following is the bleeding vessel in extradural hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Middle meningeal artery

Explanation: The bleeding vessel responsible for extradural Hemorrhage (epidural Hemorrhage) is the middle meningeal artery.

Intracranial haemorrhages

  • The first layer is the skull vault (cranium), followed by the dura mater, arachnoid mater, pia mater, and brain tissue (cerebrum).
  • The space between the skull and dura contains the middle meningeal artery.
  • The middle meningeal artery is most prominent at the pterion, the point where the frontal, parietal, sphenoid, and temporal bones meet.

 

Space and Hemorrhages

Location

Blood vessel involved

Epidural Space/ Hemorrhage

Between the skull vault and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to epidural hematoma.

Middle meningeal artery

(Option A)

Subdural Space/ Hemorrhage

Between the arachnoid and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to subdural hematoma.

Bridging veins (which drain into the dural venous sinus)

(Option B ruled out)

Subarachnoid Space/ Hemorrhage

Between the arachnoid and pia mater

Arteries of the circle of Willis (Middle cerebral artery, Anterior communicating artery -most commonly) (Option C ruled out)

Anterior cerebral artery (Option D) is not involved in extradural hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for parathyroidectomy in a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism?

choices.text: Serum calcium > 1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Creatinine clearance < 90 mL/min

Explanation:

  • Creatinine clearance < 90 mL/min is not an indication for parathyroidectomy.

Indications for Parathyroidectomy:

  • Serum calcium > 0.25 mmol/L (1.0 mg/dL) above the upper limit of normal. (Option A)
  • Bone Mineral Density (BMD) by DEXA: T-score ≤ -2.5 at the lumbar spine, total hip, femoral neck, or distal one-third of radius.
  • Vertebral fracture.
  • Creatinine clearance < 60 mL/min.
  • 24-hour urinary calcium > 10 mmol/dL (>400 mg/day) (Option B) or increased risk of stone formation
  • Age < 50 years (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly affected nerve after parotid surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Facial nerve

Explanation:

  • The facial nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in parotid surgery as it traverses perpendicularly through the parotid gland.
  • The cervical branch of facial nerve is involved in this
  • It leads to Bell's palsy

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: Though they supply the parotid gland, they are not commonly injured

questions.text: What skin condition is characterized by the presence of coral red fluorescence under a woods lamp?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Erythrasma

Explanation:

  • Erythrasma is a superficial bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. It commonly affects intertriginous areas (groin, axillae, inframammary folds, and toe webs) and presents as well-defined, reddish-brown patches with mild scaling.
  • A key diagnostic feature is its coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp, which occurs due to protoporphyrin production by Corynebacterium minutissimum.

Erythrasma:

  • Erythrasma is a superficial skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.
  • Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, obesity, immunocompromised state, hyperhidrosis, older adults
  • It usually presents as asymptomatic lesions in the following areas:
    • Interdigital: Scaling, fissuring plaques, maceration
    • Intertriginous: Hyperpigmented patches, mild scaling, wrinkling
    • Genital/perianal: Pruritis ani
  • Interdigital erythrasma commonly occurs with dermatophyte or candidal infections
  • Wood's lamp examination shows coral-red fluorescence from coproporphyrin III produced by Corynebacterium minutissimum.
  • Treatment:
    • First line: Topical antibacterials (Fusidic acid, Clarithromycin) or topical antifungal (Miconazole)
    • Second line: Photodynamic therapy using porphyrin

 

  • Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic procedure used to observe fluorescence patterns in the skin under ultraviolet light.
  • It helps identify fungal infections, bacterial infections, pigmentary disorders, and other skin conditions based on characteristic fluorescence reactions
  • This non-invasive test is conducted in a darkened room, emitting light of wavelength 320-450nm.

Disease

Colour on Wood’s light

Vitiligo

Milky white

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Yellow

Tinea capitis

Green

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and is viewed with Wood’s light

Porphyria

Fluorescence observed in urine, teeth and blood

Tuberous sclerosis

Ash-leaf macules

 

Incorrect Options:

Acanthosis nigricans (Option B): Characterized by hyperpigmented, velvety plaques in intertriginous areas, associated with insulin resistance. It does not fluoresce under a Wood's lamp.

Allergic Contact Dermatitis (Option C): Presents with erythema, vesicles, and pruritus after exposure to allergens. It does not fluoresce under a Wood's lamp.

Cutaneous Candidiasis (Option D): Presents with erythematous, satellite pustules in moist areas but typically shows pale white or yellow fluorescence under Wood’s lamp, not coral red.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with severe pain and swelling in her right hand, which is increasing in size and severity. She had a prick injury in the garden 5 days ago. On examination, she cries out in pain when her hand is extended and when the palmar aspect is palpated passively. Which of the following statements is true about the condition?

choices.text: More common in the dorsal aspect of the hand
X-ray imaging will aid in the location of the foreign body in all patients
Oral analgesics are the mainstay of treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It requires incision and drainage

Explanation:

The patient likely has a deep palmar abscess secondary to a foreign body, and incision and drainage (I&D) is required to relieve pressure, remove the foreign body, and treat the infection.

Deep Palmar Infection: These infections begin in the palm and may be confined to a web space initially. As the infection progresses, the entire hand becomes swollen and tender due to the accumulation of pus on either side of the septum.

  • Management:
    • The treatment involves incision and drainage (I&D) with a thorough washout of the wound.
    • It's essential to open all affected deep spaces. In some cases, incisions may be needed on both the dorsal and volar sides of the hand.
    • If the extent of the infection is unclear, imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI can be used to delineate the spread within the deep palmar spaces.

Incorrect Options:

More common in the dorsal aspect of the hand (Option A): Infections or abscesses caused by foreign bodies are more common in the palmar aspect due to the tighter fascial compartments.

X-ray imaging will aid in the location of the foreign body in all patients (Option B): X-rays are not always helpful, especially for non-radio-opaque foreign bodies (wood), so other imaging like ultrasound might be more useful.

Oral analgesics (Option D) may help manage pain, but they are not sufficient for treating the underlying infection/abscess, which requires I&D.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in MMR?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Death due to RTA

Explanation:

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a key indicator used in public health to measure the health outcomes related to pregnancy and childbirth. It represents the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal deaths included in the MMR are those that occur during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days after the termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management, but not from accidental or incidental causes.
  • Death due to a Road Traffic Accident (RTA) would be considered an accidental cause and therefore would not be included in the maternal mortality rate (MMR).

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty breathing, and fatigue. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

  • The X-Ray image is suggestive of Constrictive pericarditis and the clinical features are also consistent with Constrictive pericarditis.
  • It is a condition in which granulation tissue formation in the pericardium results in loss of pericardial elasticity leading to restriction in the ventricular filling
  • X-ray appearance: Egg in cup appearance
  • IOC: CT scan

Constrictive Pericarditis:

Pathophysiology:

  • Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

 

Investigations:

Investigation

Purpose/Details

Chest X-ray
  • Egg in a cup appearance
  • Detects pericardial calcification, a key diagnostic clue.

Echocardiography

Visualises thickened pericardium and assesses cardiac function.

CT scanning

Helps in visualising pericardial calcification.

Complex echo-Doppler and cardiac catheterisation

  • Square root wave sign
  • Used to differentiate constrictive pericarditis from restrictive cardiomyopathy when diagnosis is uncertain.

 

Management:

Management Type

Treatment

Purpose/Details

Medical Management

Diuretics (e.g., loop diuretics, spironolactone)

Helps manage diastolic heart failure by reducing fluid overload.

Surgical Management

Pericardiectomy

 

Definitive treatment through surgical removal of the diseased pericardium. Significant improvement is possible, but the procedure has high complication risk and suboptimal outcomes in up to 50% of patients.

Bronchial asthma (Option B): This can present as pulmonary hyperinflation, bronchial wall thickening and peribronchial cuffing

Acute pericarditis (Option C): A flask shaped, enlarged cardiac silhouette will be observed in this condition.

Atrial myxoma (Option D): This can present with cardiomegaly, left atrial enlargement, vascular redistribution, prominent pulmonary trunk

questions.text: A young boy came to the OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. Which ofthe following transmits the condition described in the scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mite

Explanation:

  • The child’s symptoms of severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between the fingers are characteristic of scabies, which is caused by Sarcoptes scabiei (a mite).

Scabies:

  • Parasitic infection of the skin caused by Sarcoptes scabiei (itch mite).
  • Mode of spread: Scabies are highly contagious, and transmission is by skin-to-skin contact and fomites. Risk factors include poor personal hygiene.

Clinical manifestation:

  • The characteristic sign of scabies is the presence of burrows, Are thin, grayish-white or skin-colored, linear or wavy lines found in areas like the webbing between fingers, wrists, elbows, armpits, waistline, buttocks, genital area, and ankles, causing intense itching, especially at night.
  • Examination typically reveals excoriated papules, typically over the web spaces of the fingers (as shown in the image).

Other areas of the body that must be examined for lesions include:

  • The medial aspect of the wrist
  • The medial aspect of the forearm
  • Umbilicus
  • Axilla
  • Nipple
  • Genitalia/ groin- burrows (wavy, grey tunnels)

 

This distribution is called the circle of Hebra.

The face is typically spared, due to high amounts of sebum in the facial skin.

Circle of Hebra demonstrating the typical location of scabies lesions

Incorrect Options:

Louse (Option A): Lice (Pediculus humanus capitis, Pediculus humanus corporis, Pthirus pubis) cause pediculosis (head/body/pubic lice), which presents with itching and nits attached to hair shafts, not burrows in the skin.

Tick (Option B): Ticks are blood-feeding arachnids that transmit diseases like Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and babesiosis. They do not burrow into the skin or cause widespread itching.

Flea (Option D): Fleas (Pulex irritans) cause pruritic papules, often in a clustered pattern ("breakfast, lunch, and dinner" sign), but they do not form burrows in the skin.

questions.text: Radioactive isotope used for teletherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cobalt-60

Explanation:

  • Cobalt-60 is the most commonly used radioactive isotope in teletherapy, a type of external beam radiotherapy. It emits high-energy gamma rays, which are effective for treating deep-seated tumors.

Teletherapy (External beam radiation)

  • It is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed at a distance from the body, delivering high-energy radiation beams to treat tumors.
  • External beam sources are:
    • Betatron
    • Cobalt
    • Linear accelerator
    • Neutron beam
    • Photon beam
    • Proton beam
    • Spray radiation
    • Stereotactic radiosurgery such as gamma knife
    • X-ray

Types of Beams

Electrons
  • Negatively charged particles
  • Limited penetration
  • Effective for tumors near the body surface (Skin tumors)

Photons

  • Can reach deep tumors
  • Scatter radiation along the path
  • Continue through normal tissue after reaching the tumor
  • Made up of high energy:
    • X-rays (LINAC- Linear accelerators)
    • Gamma rays

Protons
  • Positively charged particles
  • No radiation scatter
  • Stop precisely at the tumor location

 

cobalt 60 (Co60)

Linear accelerator
  • The Cobalt machine produces an artificial radioisotope (Co )
  • Advantage: Relative constancy of beam output
  • Source replacement approximately every 4 to 5 years
  • LINAC- Linear accelerators do not need a radioisotope
  • The fast-moving electron beam generates radiation which is used in radiotherapy
  • X-ray beams are produced

Advantages of External Beam

  • Painless
  • Do not require a hospital stay in most patients
  • Most patients can continue with their normal daily activities
  • Non-invasive

Iridium-192 (Option A): Used in brachytherapy, especially for treating cancers of the cervix, breast, and prostate.

Iodine-125 (Option B): Used in brachytherapy, particularly for prostate cancer and eye plaques (e.g., choroidal melanoma).

Iodine-131 (Option D): Used in the treatment of thyroid cancer and hyperthyroidism but not in teletherapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher presents to the physician with complaints of hoarseness and voice fatigue. She reports that these symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past few months, especially towards the end of the school day. She denies any history of smoking or excessive alcohol consumption. Flexible laryngoscopy image is given below. what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Vocal nodule

Explanation:

  • Vocal nodule is a bilateral sessile swelling at the region of junction of anterior and middle 1/3rd of vocal cords
  • It is mostly seen in teachers, singers, etc

 

Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule)

Cause

Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers. )

Laterality

Bilateral or symmetrical

Location

 

 

Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This

is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord.

Appearance

 

Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage

Symptoms

Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation.

Treatment

 

 
  • Initially, voice rest.
  • If it fails -
  • microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament
  • Speech therapy

 

Incorrect Options:

Reinkes edema (Option B):

  • This is an accumulation of the oedematous tissue or the myxomatous tissue in Reinke's space.
  • It involves the anterior ⅔ rd which is the membranous portion of the vocal cord.
  • It has a Bag with a water-like appearance due to bilateral symmetrical swellings of the vocal cord

 

Vocal polyp (Option C):

  • This is a unilateral pedunculated lesion present at the junction of anterior and middle ⅓ rd of vocal chords.

 

Keratosis larynx (Option D):

  • Causes due to chronic irritation by smoking, tobacco chewing, excessive voice abuse, and reflux.
  • Can be treated by Stripping of the vocal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following provides valuable information about the reproductive behavior of couples within a population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) TFR

Explanation:

  • The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the average number of children born to a woman over her reproductive lifetime (15-49 years), usually expressed per woman.
  • It is a common measure used to assess fertility levels within a population. TFR takes into account the age-specific fertility rates of women across all reproductive ages.
  • TFR provides valuable information about the reproductive behavior of couples within a population and is used by demographers and policymakers to understand trends in population growth, as well as to formulate policies related to family planning, healthcare, and social services.

Incorrect Options:

NRR (Option B):

  • Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is the number of daughters or girls a newborn girl will bear or will have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates.
  • NRR is a mortality dependent fertility indicator.

GFR (Option C):

  • General Fertility Rate (GFR ) is the total number of live births in an area in a year per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) in a year.
  • Not everyone in the reproductive age group is exposed to the risk of childbirth.

GRR (Option D):

  • Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR) is the total number of girls a woman will have throughout her reproductive age, considering the current age-specific fertility pattern and with out mortality. · GRR is given by TFR for girl children.

questions.text: Blood cholesterol shown as mg/ml value is in which scale?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Continuous

Explanation:

  • Continuous data refers to data that can take any value within a given range and can be measured with a high degree of precision.
  • Continuous data can include decimal values and can theoretically take on an infinite number of possible values within the specified range.
  • Examples of continuous data include height, weight, temperature, and blood cholesterol levels (measured in mg/dL or mmol/L).
  • In the context of blood cholesterol levels, they are measured on a continuous scale because they can take on any value within a range (e.g., from 100 mg/dL to 300 mg/dL) and can be measured with a high degree of precision using laboratory methods.

Incorrect Options:

Ordinal (Option A):

  • Ordinal data refers to data that have a defined order or ranking but the differences between the values are not meaningful or consistent.
  • For example, ranking students based on their exam scores (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.) represents ordinal data because while there is a ranking order, the difference in scores between students may not be uniform or meaningful.

Nominal (Option B):

  • Nominal data refers to categorical data where the categories are unordered and have no inherent numerical value.
  • For example, colors (red, blue, green) or types of fruits (apple, banana, orange) represent nominal data because there is no inherent order or ranking among the categories.

Discrete (Option C):

  • Discrete data refers to data that can only take specific, distinct values and cannot take on values between these points. Discrete data are usually counts of items or events and are typically represented by whole numbers.
  • For example, the number of students in a classroom or the number of cars in a parking lot are examples of discrete data.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a testicular mass, and a gross image of the mass is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Seminoma

Explanation:

The testicular mass described, with a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface and no signs of haemorrhage or necrosis, is most consistent with a diagnosis of Seminoma.

  • It is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma, and germinoma is present in the pineal gland.
  • Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade.
  • Genetics: Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 & NANOG.
  • Gross:
    • Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.
    • Generally, the tunica albuginea is not penetrated, but extension to the epididymis, spermatic cord, or scrotal sac occasionally occurs.
  • Histology of seminoma:
    • It consists of sheets of monomorphic cells arranged in poorly defined lobules, separated by fibrous septa with lymphocytic (T cell) infiltration.
    • Classic seminoma cells are large, round to polyhedral, with distinct membranes, central nuclei, and prominent nucleoli.
    • The cytoplasm is clear or watery containing glycogen.

 

Teratoma (Option A) are germ cell tumours containing tissues from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm). They can be benign (mature) or malignant (immature) and are commonly found in the testes, ovaries, or midline. Histologically, they present as heterogeneous masses with various tissue types (e.g., neural, muscle, epidermis, cartilage, thyroid, or intestinal tissue), often showing necrosis, calcification, or hair/teeth/bone.

 

Yolk sac tumor (Option C ) is a malignant germ cell tumour, commonly found in the testes or ovaries, especially in children and young adults. It produces alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and appears as a solid mass with haemorrhage and necrosis, presenting in younger patients, particularly in the first two years of life. Microscopically, show a lace-like network of cuboidal or spindled cells with Schiller-Duval bodies and eosinophilic globules containing α-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Choriocarcinoma (Option D) is a rare, highly malignant germ cell tumour, typically in the testes, ovaries, or placenta, that secretes hCG. It presents with pain, swelling, and elevated hCG levels, often with haemorrhage, necrosis, and mixed trophoblastic cells. Microscopically, it contains syncytiotrophoblasts (multinucleated, hCG-containing) and cytotrophoblasts (polygonal, clear cytoplasm).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a swelling in the back of his neck that has been present for almost a year. The swelling has not increased in size. On examination, it is non-pulsatile, and the slip sign is positive, with the swelling measuring 3x3 cm. Which of the following statements is most likely true?

choices.text: Excision can be done if the patient requests it

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Excision can be done if the patient requests it

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical features (non-pulsatile, stable size, and positive slip sign), this is most likely a lipoma, which is a benign tumour of fatty tissue. If the patient requests excision, and if there are no concerns about malignancy, excision can be performed to remove the lipoma for cosmetic or symptomatic reasons.

Lipoma:

  • A lipoma is a benign tumour composed of mature adipocytes (fat cells) and is the most common soft tissue tumor.
  • These tumors are generally soft, mobile, and painless masses found beneath the skin.
  • Most frequently found on the trunk, shoulders, neck, and arms.
  • Histologically, lipomas consist of mature fat cells that are identical to normal adipose tissue but are encapsulated by a thin fibrous capsule, distinguishing them from the surrounding tissue.
  • Lipomas are typically slow-growing, soft, and non-tender.
  • They are usually asymptomatic but can cause discomfort if they compress nearby structures or are located in a site prone to friction or pressure.
  • On physical examination, lipomas are well-circumscribed, mobile masses that can vary in size from a few millimetres to several centimetres.
  • Slip sign: Positive
  • Very low risk of malignant transformation into liposarcoma. (Option A)

 

Management:

  • Most lipomas do not require treatment unless they become symptomatic, grow rapidly, or cause cosmetic concerns.
  • Surgical excision is the definitive treatment and is usually curative.
  • Liposuction may also be an option for larger lipomas, but complete excision is preferred to prevent recurrence.

While FNAC can be used for diagnosing soft tissue masses, it is not always required if the lesion's clinical presentation is typical of a lipoma. In many cases, a clinical diagnosis based on history and examination (such as soft, mobile, non-tender mass) is sufficient. (Option B)

PET scans are generally used for staging known malignancies, such as lymphoma or other aggressive cancers. In this case, there is no indication that this is a malignant lesion, so a PET scan is unnecessary. (Option C)

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Line diagram

Explanation:

  • The above-given graph is a line diagram/line chart. It depicts the trends of events or incidence of cases over time, showing both rises and falls.

Incorrect Options:

Scattered diagram (Option C):

  • It consists of a collection of points, each representing the value of one variable plotted against the value of another variable.

Frequency polygon (Option D):

  • The frequency polygon is obtained by joining the mid-points of the histogram blocks.

questions.text: During laparoscopic surgery, while inserting the trocar, which of the following is most prone to injury?

choices.text: Both superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both superior and inferior epigastric arteries

Explanation:

  • Both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries are at the highest risk during trocar placement due to their superficial and relatively consistent anatomical location in the anterior abdominal wall.
  • The superior and inferior epigastric arteries run vertically within the posterior rectus sheath along the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle. This creates a high-risk zone for injury during trocar insertion, especially in the lower abdomen.
  • The superior epigastric artery descends from the internal thoracic artery, while the inferior epigastric artery ascends from the external iliac artery. These arteries anastomose within the rectus muscle. Their consistent anatomical location and superficial course within the anterior abdominal wall make them particularly vulnerable to injury when a trocar is placed incorrectly.

questions.text: Heme is derived from which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glycine

Explanation

Glycine combines with succinyl-CoA in the first step of heme synthesis, catalyzed by the enzyme δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthase. This reaction is the rate-limiting step in heme biosynthesis.

Glutamine (Option A): Glutamine is involved in nucleotide biosynthesis and ammonia transport but does not play a direct role in heme synthesis.

Glutamate (Option C): Glutamate is primarily involved in the synthesis of glutathione and neurotransmitters but does not contribute to heme synthesis.

Valine (Option D): Valine is a branched-chain amino acid involved in protein synthesis and energy production but not in heme biosynthesis.

questions.text: Which receptor plays a crucial role in glucose uptake by skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) GLUT 4

Explanation

  • GLUT 4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter predominantly found in heart, skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. It translocates to the cell membrane in response to insulin, facilitating glucose uptake during periods of increased energy demand.
  • GLUT proteins are distributed in various tissues according to their specific functions.

Transporter

Tissue Location

Functions

GLUT 1

(Option A ruled out)

Brain, kidney, colon, placenta, erythrocytes

Facilitates glucose uptake

GLUT 2

(Option B ruled out)

Liver, pancreatic β cells, small intestine, kidney

Enables rapid glucose uptake or release

GLUT 3

(Option C ruled out)

Brain, kidney, placenta

Assists in glucose uptake

GLUT 4

(Option D)

Heart and skeletal muscle, adipose tissue

Mediates insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

GLUT 5

Small intestine

Facilitates fructose absorption

SGLT 1

Small intestine and kidney

Actively transports glucose against a concentration gradient

GLUT 1-5 are facilitative bidirectional transporters, whereas SGLT 1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT/ gene expert?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MTB+ Rifampicin resistance

Explanation:CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) or GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic tool that is primarily used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and for identifying rifampicin resistance. Rifampicin resistance is a key indicator for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB), which is a major concern in TB management. The GeneXpert system detects MTB DNA and also tests for rifampicin resistance by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene of the bacteria, which are responsible for resistance to this drug.

TB lab investigations:

Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.

 

Line Probe Assay (LPA)

 
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option A): While the GeneXpert can detect MTB, the test is primarily used for identifying rifampicin resistance in addition to detecting the bacterium itself.

MTB + Isoniazid (Option C): While isoniazid resistance can be important in TB treatment, CBNAAT/GeneXpert is not specifically designed to detect isoniazid resistance; it's more focused on rifampicin resistance.

MTB + Ethambutol (Option D): Similar to isoniazid, ethambutol resistance is not typically tested for by GeneXpert.

questions.text: A Patient who has a pet dog at home complains of hypochondrial pain. Radiological imaging shows a multilocular cyst within the liver. The organism involved is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Echinococcus granulosus

Explanation: The patient’s symptoms of hypochondrial pain (pain in the upper abdomen), along with radiological findings of a multilocular cyst in the liver, strongly suggest an infection with Echinococcus granulosus, which causes hydatid disease.

Echinococcus granulosus

Other name

Dog tapeworm

Definitive Host

Dog (optimal host), wolf, jackal and fox

Intermediate Host

Sheep and cattle

Accidental Intermediate Host

Man (Harbors larval stage, not adult form)

Infective Form

Embryonated egg

Mode of Infection

Ingestion of the eggs due to:

  • Intimate handling of infected dogs
  • Eating raw vegetables or other food items contaminated with dog feces

Eggs

  • Ovoid in shape and brown in color
  • Contains an embryo with three pairs of hooklets

Larva

Represent structure of scolex of adult worm and remains invaginated within a vesicular body.

Adult Worm
  • Consist of scolex, a short neck and strobila
  • Scolex is pyriform, with four suckers and prominent rostellum bearing two circular rows of hooklets.

                                                Life Cycle:

 

Hydatid Cyst

Hydatid cysts are parasitic cysts caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

Commonly Affected Organs

  • Liver (most common site, about 60-70% of cases)
  • Lungs (second most common site)
  • Other organs (rare but possible): Brain, spleen, kidneys, bones, and peritoneum

Clinical Features:

  • Asymptomatic Phase: Common due to slow cyst growth.
  • Symptomatic Phase:
    • Liver Involvement: Mostly right lobe; Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, obstructive jaundice, portal hypertension.
    • Lung Involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea, hemoptysis, pneumothorax.

Layers of a hydatid cyst

Layer

Name

Origin

Description

Main Function

Outer Layer

Pericyst

Host-derived
  • Thick fibrous layer created by the host's inflammatory response around the cyst.
  • Eventually it develops into a dense fibrous capsule which may even calcify.

Provides structural support and isolates the cyst from surrounding tissues.

Middle Layer

Ectocyst (Laminated Membrane)

Parasite-derived
  • Acellular,chitinous, laminated hyaline layer secreted by the parasite.
  • Has the appearance of the white of a hard boiled egg.

Acts as a barrier against host immune cells and protects the inner germinal layer.

Inner Layer

Endocyst (Germinal Layer)

Parasite-derived
  • Thin cellular layer lining the cyst interior.
  • Consist of a number of nuclei embedded in a protoplasmic mass.
  • Vital layer of the cyst.
  • Site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.
  • Also secrete hydatid fluid, which fills the cyst.

Entamoeba histolytica (Option B): This protozoan causes amoebic liver abscesses, which can also lead to right upper quadrant pain. However, the cysts in amoebic infections are typically unilocular, not multilocular, and are usually associated with a history of dysentery or diarrhea.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option C): This is a parasitic roundworm that causes strongyloidiasis and may lead to abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, it does not typically cause multilocular cysts in the liver.

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option D): This hookworm is associated with hookworm infection, causing symptoms like anemia and abdominal discomfort, but it does not lead to liver cysts.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is not included in the definition of severe Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Looping in all quadrants

Explanation:

Looping in all quadrants is not a criterion in severe NPDR.

Abbreviated Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) classification of diabetic retinopathy

Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

 

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants (Option B ruled out)
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants (Option D ruled out)
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants (Option A ruled out)

Review in 4 months

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months
