questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought with complaints of headache, vomiting, and neck stiffness for a few days. He had undergone a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt placement for hydrocephalus a year ago. What is the most common cause of shunt malfunction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Shunt obstruction

Explanation:

Shunt obstruction is the most common cause of VP shunt malfunction. This can occur anywhere along the length of the shunt, but it often happens at the distal catheter (the part of the shunt that drains into the peritoneum).

A Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is generally considered for long-term management of hydrocephalus. It is implanted surgically to divert excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles of the brain to the peritoneal cavity, where it can be absorbed by the body.

Management of Hydrocephalus:

  • Medical: Acetazolamide and furosemide can temporarily reduce CSF production but are not effective long-term.
  • Surgical: (CSF Diversion)
    • Ventriculoperitoneal Shunt: Valved tubing from the ventricle to the peritoneal cavity.
    • Endoscopic Third Ventriculostomy: It is a useful treatment for certain cases of hydrocephalus, especially when there is an obstructive pattern that can be bypassed surgically and not always suitable for all patients and is considered an alternative to shunt placement
  • Intrauterine Treatment: Results are generally poor except in cases associated with fetal meningomyelocele.

Complications: Shunt occlusion (headache, papilledema, vomiting, altered mental status) and bacterial infection leading to meningitis/peritonitis (fever, headache, meningismus), typically caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with diplopia and ataxia, and he was completely confused. A history of alcohol was noted. What is the initial treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IV Thiamine

Explanation:

  • The given case, presenting with confusion, diplopia, and ataxia, along with a history of alcoholism, is diagnosed as Wernicke's Encephalopathy (also known as Alcoholic Encephalopathy), with intravenous thiamine being the initial treatment of choice.
  • It is an acute, potentially life-threatening neurological syndrome resulting from thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly found in chronic alcoholics.
  • The classic triad of symptoms in Wernicke's encephalopathy includes
    • Encephalopathy (confusion),
    • Oculomotor dysfunction (painful eye movements, nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia)
    • Ataxia.
  • The 6th cranial nerve (which controls lateral movement of the eye) is also involved.
  • Other eye signs may include a sluggish reaction to light and anisocoria (unequal pupillary size).
  • It may progress to Korsakoff syndrome (Korsakoff psychosis).

 

  Wernicke's Encephalopathy Korsakoff Syndrome
Onset Acute Chronic often follows Wernicke's syndrome
Key Symptoms
  • Global Confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)
  • Ataxia (especially gait)
  • Severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine (Option B)

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

 

IV Lorazepam (Option A) is a benzodiazepine that is not effective for Wernicke’s encephalopathy but is the preferred treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms. It is also used to control seizures and manage status epilepticus.

IV fluid + dextrose (Option C) is also helpful in the management of Wernicke’s encephalopathy but is not the initial step of management.

Vitamin B12 (Option D) is also used in the management of Wernicke’s encephalopathy but is not the initial step of management.

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with an empty delta sign.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cerebral venous thrombosis

Explanation:

  • The empty delta sign is a radiological finding seen on contrast-enhanced CT scans or MR venography.
  • It indicates the presence of a thrombus in the dural venous sinus, most commonly the superior sagittal sinus.
  • The thrombus appears as a filling defect surrounded by contrast enhancement, forming a triangular or delta-shaped void.

Central venous sinus thrombosis

  • CVT should be suspected in patients presenting with headaches, seizures, or encephalopathy.
  • Can occur in superficial or deep dural venous sinuses, affecting either isolated veins or as part of broader venous sinus thrombosis.
  • Factors like intracranial infections, trauma, dehydration, pregnancy, oral contraceptives, smoking, and vasculitis (e.g., Behçet disease) can trigger CVT. If absent, a thrombophilia screening is necessary.

CT Findings:

 

  • The empty delta sign, visible in contrast-enhanced CT scans, indicates dural venous sinus thrombosis in the superior sagittal sinus as a triangular filling defect outlined by contrast, representing a thrombus.
  • The dense vein sign, a hyperdense vessel sign indicating hyperattenuating thrombus due to acute venous thrombosis, is found in cortical veins or dural venous sinuses.

MRI Findings:

  • Loss of normal flow void; thrombosed vessels may appear hyperintense on T1 and T2 sequences. Very acute thrombus can be hypointense on T2, mimicking flow voids. Additionally, slow flow can also result in loss of the flow void.
  • MR venography (MRV) shows a loss of flow signal or irregularity, indicating a thrombus.
  • SWI (Susceptibility Weighted Imaging) can highlight thrombosed veins and detect acute hemorrhage.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option A): Typically presents with hyperdense blood in the basal cisterns or sulci on non-contrast CT, not an empty delta sign.

Subdural hemorrhage (Option B): Appears as a crescent-shaped hyperdensity along the brain's surface, unrelated to the venous sinuses.

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage (Option D): Appears as a hyperdense lesion within the brain parenchyma on non-contrast CT and is not associated with the empty delta sign

questions.text: The chest X-ray shows right-sided white-out lung and contralateral tracheal deviation. In which of the following conditions is this seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thoracic mass

Explanation:

  • The radiological findings indicate a tracheal deviation to the side opposite to the white-out lung field due to a thoracic mass (mainly due to massive pleural effusion).
  • This pattern occurs when a space-occupying lesion or massive fluid collection (such as due to a lung cancer) in the thoracic cavity creates enough mass effect to push the mediastinal structures away from the affected side.
  • The pleural fluid is seen as opacity (single large black arrow) with lateral upward sloping of a meniscus- shaped contour.
  • The right diaphragmatic contour is also completely obliterated, indicating presence of fluid in the right pleural space.
  • In spite of a moderately large right pleural effusion, the trachea appears to be slightly shifted to the right side (as depicted by small black arrows) indicating an underlying lung pathology on the right side.

Pneumothorax (Option A) typically presents with a hyperlucent lung field without vascular markings due to air collection in the pleural space. In this X-ray, we see opacity rather than hyperlucency.

Consolidation (Option B) shows haziness or opacity on X-ray but maintains some visualization of underlying vascular markings. A complete white-out appearance is not typical. Furthermore, significant tracheal deviation is not a characteristic feature of simple consolidation.

Collapse of the lung (Option C) would show tracheal deviation toward the same side as the opacity, not away from it. This is because collapse creates negative pressure that pulls the mediastinal structures toward the affected side.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a recent travel history to Africa presents with fever, confusion and neurological deficits. Laboratory analysis reveals the following findings. This organism exhibits a specific property that facilitates sequestration in vascular beds to avoid splenic clearance. What is the phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cytoadherence

Explanation: The patient’s symptoms, including fever, confusion, and neurological deficits, along with the travel history to Africa, suggest a Plasmodium falciparum infection, which is the causative agent of severe malaria. Plasmodium falciparum has a specific property that facilitates its sequestration in the microvasculature, especially in organs like the brain (leading to cerebral malaria), by adhering to the endothelial cells of blood vessels. This process is known as cytoadherence.

Plasmodium falciparum is the primary species associated with cytoadherence, where infected red blood cells adhere to endothelial cells in blood vessels. This leads to complications like cerebral malaria due to vessel blockage and reduced blood flow.

Pathogenesis of Malignant Malaria:

Cytoadherence:

  • In Plasmodium falciparum malaria, late-stage schizonts secrete proteins that create knob-like protrusions on the surfaces of infected RBCs. This results in the expression of the adhesive protein PfEMP-1 (P. falciparum Erythrocyte Membrane Protein), which makes the infected RBCs sticky.
  • Inflammatory cytokines, particularly IFN-γ, enhance the expression of endothelial receptors such as thrombospondin, E-selectin, VCAM-1, and ICAM-1 in the brain, chondroitin sulfate B in the placenta, and CD36 in most other organs. These receptors promote the cytoadherence of infected

  • RBCs to the endothelium, leading to blockage of capillaries and venules.

Rosette formation: Infected RBCs can adhere to uninfected RBCs, forming rosettes.

Auto-Agglutination: The phenomenon where parasitised red blood cells (RBCs) clump together

These mechanisms cause capillary plugging and reduced microcirculation in vital organs, including the brain, kidneys, lungs, spleen, intestines, bone marrow, and placenta, resulting in severe complications like cerebral malaria.

Other notable virulence factors:

  • Histidine-rich protein II (HRP II)
  • Glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)

Rosetting (Option A): This refers to the formation of clusters of uninfected red blood cells around an infected red blood cell. It is a phenomenon observed in Plasmodium falciparum infections, but cytoadherence is the more accurate term for the process responsible for sequestration in the microvasculature.

Agglutination (Option B): This refers to the clumping of cells or particles, typically used to describe antibody-antigen interactions. It is not related to the sequestration of parasitized red blood cells in malaria.

Schizogony (Option D): This is the asexual reproductive process of Plasmodium, during which the parasite undergoes multiple rounds of division inside red blood cells. It is a key part of the parasite's life cycle but does not describe the sequestration mechanism that causes the clinical manifestations seen in malaria.

questions.text: A patient with meningitis was examined. His CSF shows lymphocytosis, decreased glucose, and increased protein. What is the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Explanation: The CSF (cerebrospinal fluid) findings of lymphocytosis, decreased glucose, and increased protein are characteristic of tuberculous meningitis, which is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB).

Tuberculous Meningitis

  • Tuberculous meningitis presents with a subacute course of headaches, mental changes, and fever over weeks, with CSF findings of lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein, and low glucose. Cobweb coagulum seen in CSF.

Cobweb coagulum

  • Cranial nerve palsies and hydrocephalus can occur.
  • AFB smear is often negative, and diagnosis may rely on culture or Xpert MTB/RIF assay.

TB Meningitis

Pathophysiology
  • Tuberculous Meningitis results from hematogenous spread of primary or postprimary TB or rupture of a subependymal tubercle into the subarachnoid space.

Onset

Evolves over 1–2 weeks, slower than bacterial meningitis.

Symptoms
  • Early Symptoms
    • Headache, mild mental changes, low-grade fever, malaise, anorexia, irritability over several weeks.
  • Advanced Symptoms
    • Severe headache, confusion, lethargy, altered sensorium, neck rigidity, cranial nerve palsies (especially ocular). Can progress to coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension.

Lumbar Puncture Findings (CSF)
  • High leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL), typically lymphocyte predominance
  • Protein: 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL)
  • Low glucose concentration
  • AFB is rarely seen; repeated lumbar punctures increase yield.
  • CSF culture diagnostic in up to 80% (gold standard).

Xpert MTB/RIF Assay
  • Sensitivity up to 80%.
  • A negative result does not exclude TB.

Imaging
  • CT, MRI: Shows hydrocephalus and enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

Basal cistern enhancement

  • In >50% of cases, old pulmonary lesions or military pattern on CXR.

Treatment

Immediate treatment with positive Xpert MTB/RIF.

  • Chemotherapy is effective but neurologic sequelae occur in 25% of cases, especially with delayed diagnosis.
  • Glucocorticoid Therapy
    • Dexamethasone reduces mortality and severe disability but may not prevent neurological sequelae.
    • Regimen: 0.4 mg/kg/day IV, tapering weekly, followed by oral tapering. WHO recommends tapering over 6–8 weeks.

Lymphocytosis (Option A): The presence of lymphocytes in the CSF suggests a chronic infection or inflammation, which is typical of tuberculous meningitis.

Decreased glucose (Option B): Low glucose levels in the CSF are a hallmark of tuberculous meningitis (as well as other forms of bacterial meningitis), as the bacteria consume glucose. This is often seen in tuberculosis-related infections.

Increased protein (Option C): Elevated protein levels in the CSF are also consistent with tuberculous meningitis, which causes an inflammatory response and protein leakage into the CSF.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with a cough, fever, and pneumonia. A biopsy reveals the given findings. Which organism is responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CMV

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks and history of HIV with owl eye appearance in the image is suggestive of CMV (cytomegalovirus) pneumonia.

CMV (cytomegalovirus)

Class

Betaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.

Modes of transmission
  • Oral route, respiratory & body secretions (most common)
  • Vertical transmission
  • Sexual transmission
  • Organ transplantation
  • Blood transfusion

Host cells
  • Salivary gland
  • Kidney

Clinical features

Congenital infection

  • Most common intrauterine infection with congenital defects.
  • Common presentation:
    • Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
  • Less common presentation:
    • Microcephaly
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Intrauterine growth retardation
    • Prematurity
  • Other defects: Sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Perinatal infection

  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Occasionally, premature infants present with interstitial pneumonitis.

 

Immunocompromised

  • This is seen in AIDS, HIV, organ transplant patients and cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
  • Presentations in AIDS and HIV
    • CMV chorioretinitis
    • Progressive dementia,
    • Cranial nerve defects,
  • Presentations in Organ transplant
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia
    • Febrile leukopenia
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis
    • Graft atherosclerosis
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

 

Immunocompetent

  • Usually, it occurs following a blood transfusion.
  • It presents similar to infectious mononucleosis, but heterophile antibody tests would be negative.

Investigations

Peripheral smear: Owl’s eye appearance of inclusion bodies.

 

 

Virus isolation

It is done by

  • Human fibroblast cell line culture
  • Shell vial culture

 

Antigen detected: PP65

 

Antibody detection

It is done by ELISA, and the antibodies detected are

  • CMV IgM antibodies
  • CMV IgG antibodies
  • Against PP150 and PP65,
  • Against the PP52

 

PCR

  • Used in detecting CMV DNA
  • Quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) by PCR is the most sensitive and specific testing.

Treatment
  • Ganciclovir (Drug of choice)
  • Foscarnet (in Ganciclovir resistance)
  • CMV immunoglobulins and Ganciclovir are given to bone marrow transplant patients.

 

EBV (Epstein Barr virus) (Option A) primarily causes infectious mononucleosis, marked by fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue, and usually does not lead to pneumonia. Downey cells, or atypical lymphocytes, are large, vacuolated, and often display a ballerina skirt appearance.

 

Pox virus (Option C), like smallpox (eradicated) and molluscum contagiosum, causes skin lesions such as pustules or bumps. While they don't typically cause pneumonia, they can lead to systemic infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

Chickenpox (Option D), caused by varicella-zoster virus (VZV), leads to a rash of red spots and blisters. In immunocompromised patients, it can cause severe complications like varicella pneumonia, though less commonly than CMV or bacterial pneumonia, and may require antiviral treatment.

questions.text: A lung cancer patient has hyperpigmentation of palmar and sole creases. Which of the following is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MSH

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Ectopic Cushing's syndrome, a paraneoplastic syndrome commonly associated with lung cancer.
  • Proopiomelanocortin (POMC) produced by the tumor is cleaved to form Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH) and ACTH, leading to hyperpigmentation. This process represents one of the most common hormonally-induced paraneoplastic syndromes in small cell lung cancer (SCLC).

Ectopic Cushing's Syndrome

Definition

ACTH production from non-pituitary sources leading to Cushing's syndrome

Epidemiology

Accounts for 10-20% of cases of Cushing's syndrome

Common Sources
  • Small cell lung cancer (most common)
  • Bronchial and thymic carcinoids
  • Islet tumors
  • Pheochromocytomas
  • Medullary thyroid carcinomas

Pathophysiology
  • Increased expression of POMC gene from non-pituitary sources
  • Production of MSH, β-lipotropin, and other POMC-derived peptides
  • Production of ACTH fragments

Clinical Features
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Marked fluid retention
  • Hyperpigmentation manifestations due to MSH
  • Less marked weight gain compared to pituitary Cushing's
  • Centripetal fat redistribution
  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Glucose intolerance

Diagnosis
  • Very high ACTH levels (typically >2-3 times normal)
  • No response to high-dose dexamethasone suppression

Treatment
  • Treatment of underlying malignancy
  • Glucocorticoid receptor blockers
  • Steroidogenesis inhibitors
  • Management of complications (diabetes, hypokalemia)

Key Distinctions from Pituitary Cushing's
  • Higher ACTH levels
  • No response to dexamethasone suppression
  • More rapid onset
  • More severe metabolic complications

C-peptide (Option B) is a byproduct formed during the conversion of proinsulin to insulin. It has no role in the hyperpigmentation seen in paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer.

Neuropeptide Y (Option C) is involved in appetite regulation through hypothalamic signaling. This peptide does not contribute to the hyperpigmentation observed in paraneoplastic syndromes.

Melanin (Option D) is the end product of melanogenesis responsible for skin pigmentation. While it is the final pigment, the question asks about the hormone responsible for triggering the hyperpigmentation, which is MSH.

questions.text: Which hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Growth Hormone

Explanation:

  • Growth hormone levels increase significantly during periods of deep sleep, stress, and starvation.
  • This hormone, produced by the pituitary gland, is crucial for the body's repair and regeneration processes, which are most active during deep sleep.
  • Additionally, growth hormone release is influenced by stress and nutritional status, with levels rising in response to these conditions to support the body's adaptive responses​

Factors controlling GH secretion and their effects

Hypothalamic Control
  • Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH): Increases GH synthesis and secretion.
  • Somatostatin (GHIH): Decreases GH secretion.

Nutritional Factors
  • Hypoglycemia: Promotes GH secretion to increase blood glucose levels and mobilize energy.
  • Amino Acids: Stimulate GH release, supporting protein synthesis and growth.
  • Starvation or Protein Deficiency: This leads to elevated GH levels to conserve body proteins and utilize fats as an energy source.

Physiological Factors
  • Exercise: Enhances GH secretion
  • Sleep: GH surges during deep sleep are vital for growth and tissue repair processes.
  • Stress: Physical and emotional stressors can increase GH secretion

Hormonal Factors
  • Ghrelin: Increases GH secretion and stimulates appetite.
  • Sex Hormones (Estrogen and Testosterone): Contribute to increased GH secretion during puberty, supporting growth and development.
  • Negative Feedback Control: GH and IGF-1 levels feedback to inhibit further GH release, maintaining homeostasis and preventing excess GH production.

Glucocorticoids (Option B): While glucocorticoids like cortisol do increase during stress, they do not typically increase during deep sleep. In fact, high cortisol levels can disrupt sleep.

Cortisol (Option C): Cortisol levels increase during stress and early morning hours but not during deep sleep. Elevated cortisol at night is associated with poor sleep quality.

Prolactin (Option D): Prolactin levels can rise during sleep, but its increase is not as pronounced or consistent in response to stress and starvation as growth hormone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male soldier complained of being plagued by a painful, erosive lesion near his earlobe since his return from his duty in the desert area. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and general physical examinations reveal no other abnormalities. The punch biopsy of the leading edge of the erosion reveals the given findings. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Leishmania donovani

Explanation:

  • This patient presents with complaints of a painful, erosive lesion near his ear lobe since his return from his duty in the desert area, which points towards the diagnosis of Leishmaniasis.
  • Leishmania donovani is the causative organism for Leishmaniasis
  • Sandfly (Genus Phlebotomus) transmits Leishmaniasis (caused by Leishmania Donovani).

Kala-azar/ Black sickness/Dum-dum fever/Sandfly disease/ Visceral Leishmaniasis

Organism

Protozoan

Epidemiology

Endemic in Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal

Types
  1. Visceral (Kala-Azar): L. donovani
  2. Cutaneous: L. tropica
  3. Mucocutaneous: L. braziliensis
  4. Post-kala-azar dermal (PKLD): Immune response

Reservoir
  • Humans (non-zoonotic)

Vector
  • Sandfly (Phlebotomus argentipes): has hairy wings.

Environmental
  • Peak outbreak: November to April

Mechanism of transmission
  • Bite of sandfly
  • Blood transfusion (rare)

Incubation period
  • 10 days to 2 years. (1-4 months average)

Clinical features
  • Visceral: Fever, Weight loss, Hepatosplenomegaly, Anemia.
  • Cutaneous: Painful skin ulcers
  • Mucocutaneous: Rapid mucosal destruction of nose and oropharynx
  • PKDL: Skin nodules filled with micro-organisms

Diagnosis
  • Rapid diagnostic kits: rk39-dipstick test.
    • Used for field surveys.
  • Biopsy (Gold standard): Leishmania Donovan bodies (amastigotes)

Sandfly control measures
  • DDT: 1-2gm/m2.
  • BHC (benzene hexachloride)

Treatment
  • DOC: Single dose Liposomal amphotericin-B (LAMB)10 mg/kg
  • Alternatives:
    • Miltefosine + Paramomycin
    • Pentamidine

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as they do not show amastigotes (LD bodies) which are diagnostic.

questions.text: A young lady gave a history of unprotected intercourse four days back. She is requesting an emergency contraception. Which of the following is most suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IUCD

Explanation:

  • Implantation of the embryo takes place earliest during 6th day after intercourse
  • IUCD is effective for up to 5 days following unprotected intercourse
  • IUCD induces a foreign body-like action causing aseptic inflammation of the endometrium, reducing the chances of implantation
  • Ulipristal acetate is another method that is effective up to 5 days following unprotected coitus

 

Lng (Levonorgestrel) (Option A): Contains progesterone and must be used within 72 hrs of unprotected intercourse. It is not suitable in this case as 4 days have already passed.

OCP (Option C): Combined oral contraceptive pills (Yuzpe regimen) can be used for emergency contraception but are less effective than Levonorgestrel or IUCD and must also be taken within 72 hours.

Misoprostol (Option D): Used in medical abortion, it is not indicated for emergency contraception.

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. In which of the following conditions would this be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypercarbia

Explanation:

  • The typical hand movements shown in the image are known as asterixis or "flapping tremors. These characteristic hand movements are seen in patients of toxic-metabolic encephalopathy, potentially due to hypercarbia.

The 3 causes of toxic-metabolic encephalopathy include:

  • Hepatic encephalopathy (Increased level of ammonia)
  • Uremic encephalopathy (Increased level of urea)
  • Hypercarbia (Increased level of CO2)

This condition occurs frequently in patients with chronic CO2 retention, particularly those receiving oxygen therapy for emphysema or chronic pulmonary disease. The flapping movement is elicited by having patients extend their arms and bend their wrists back.

 

Thyrotoxicosis (Option A) presents with fine tremors. The tremor pattern is distinctly different from the coarse flapping movements seen in asterixis.

Hemiballismus (Option C) manifests with wild, flinging movements at the shoulder joint. These movements are abrupt and unilateral compared to the bilateral wrist movements seen in asterixis.

Hypoxia (Option D) typically causes disorientation and mental status changes with O2 saturation <90%. While it can cause neurological symptoms, it does not specifically produce the characteristic flapping tremor seen in this case.

questions.text: Utilizing the provided X-ray, identify the type of fracture using the Salter-Harris classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Type 2

Explanation:

  • The epiphysis is separated, carrying a small triangular fragment of metaphysis(Thurston Holland Sign). This is the type 2 epiphyseal injury according to Salter and Haris classification.

 

Salter-Harris Classification of growth plate fractures:

Type

Description

Treatment and Prognosis

Type I (Option A)

Separation of the physis (growth plate), without involvement of the metaphysis or epiphysis.
  • Excellent prognosis if treated promptly
  • Treated with immobilization and observation.

Type II (Option B)

Fracture through the physis and part of the metaphysis. The metaphyseal fragment is displaced, forming a triangle (known as the Thurston-Holland sign).
  • Good prognosis with proper treatment.
  • Treated with reduction and casting.
  • Rarely affects future growth.

Type III (Option C)

Fracture through the physis and epiphysis, with the epiphysis displaced.
  • May result in joint deformity or growth disturbance if not managed well.
  • Surgical intervention required for proper alignment and fixation.

Type IV

Fracture through the physis, metaphysis, and epiphysis. Involves all three areas.
  • Can lead to growth disturbances or joint deformity.
  • Treatment typically involves surgical fixation.

Type V (Option D)

Crushing injury of the physis (growth plate), resulting in compression and loss of the growth plate. No fracture line visible.
  • Risk of growth arrest and long-term deformities.
  • Surgical intervention required.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with fatigue, bone pains, and swollen and bleeding gums. Physical examination reveals petechiae on her skin. Which of the following can be given to treat her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vitamin C

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate scurvy, due to vitamin C deficiency.
  • The presentation includes characteristic features of impaired collagen synthesis due to vitamin C deficiency, leading to weakened blood vessels and connective tissue abnormalities.
  • Vitamin C is essential for collagen formation, and its deficiency results in the classic presentation of fatigue, bone pain, gingival changes, and easy bruising. Treatment with vitamin C supplementation typically shows rapid improvement within days.

 

Vitamin C Source:

Vitamin C Source:

Citrus fruits/juices, cauliflower and green leafy vegetables, melons, guava.

Vitamin C RDA (Infants)

0-6 months- 40 mg/day

7-12 months- 50 mg/day

Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy)

Causes:
  • Heat-treated milk or unfortified formula.
  • Diets lacking fruits and vegetables.

Symptoms:
  • Early: Irritability, loss of appetite, fever, pain, leg tenderness.
  • Later: Swelling, pseudoparalysis, subperiosteal hemorrhages, "scorbutic rosary" beads at the costochondral junction due to periosteal bleeds, gum changes, anemia, bleeding, poor healing.

Treatment:

  • Vitamin C 100-200 mg/day (oral or parenteral).
  • Improvement within a week; continue for 3 months.

 

Vitamin A (Option A): Deficiency primarily affects vision and epithelial integrity, presenting with night blindness and xerophthalmia. It does not cause the bleeding manifestations or musculoskeletal symptoms seen in this case.

Vitamin D (Option B): Deficiency leads to rickets in children with bone deformities and growth problems. While it can cause bone pain, it does not cause bleeding manifestations or gum problems.

Vitamin E (Option C): Deficiency primarily causes neurological manifestations, including cerebellar ataxia and retinopathy. It does not cause the bleeding diathesis or musculoskeletal symptoms presented in this case.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain. A CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT) abdomen was done. What is the likely source of pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Kidney

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this case, given the irregular enhancement and enlargement of the renal lesion on CECT, is Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC), making the origin of pain the kidney most likely.
  • Clinical Features of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC):
    • Classic symptoms such as hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable abdominal mass - “TOO - LATE” TRIAD seen in 10% of patients with advanced disease.
    • Systemic symptoms like weight loss, fever, and fatigue can also occur.
    • In advanced stages, RCC may metastasise to the lungs, bones, and brain.
    • A non-reducing varicocele, referred to as a suspicious varicocele, may indicate the presence of renal cell carcinoma (RCC), often due to a thrombus originating from the left RCC.

Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy (Option A): Involves removing only the tumour while preserving the remainder of the kidney.

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney
  • Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.
  • Indications: Larger tumours or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumours (T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.text: What is the recommended free residual chlorine level after chlorination of a well to ensure adequate disinfection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 0.5 ppm after 1 hour

Explanation:

  • According to standard guidelines for drinking water disinfection, a free residual chlorine level of greater than 0.5 mg/L (which is equivalent to 0.5 ppm) is required for effective disinfection.
  • This level should be maintained for a contact period of at least 1 hour to ensure that the water is adequately disinfected and safe for consumption.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D depict inadequate levels of residual chlorine for adequate disinfection.

questions.text: In the given image, the tendon marked by the arrow is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Flexor carpi radialis

Explanation:

  • The above-marked structure in the diagram is Flexor carpi radialis as it is present on the radial side of the forearm.
  • Flexor carpi radialis originates from the medial epicondyle of the humerus and inserts into the bases of the second and third metacarpal bones.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient has just undergone surgery and required a drug to reverse the muscle relaxation induced during the procedure. Which of the following drugs is used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neostigmine

Explanation:

  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is commonly used to reverse non-depolarizing muscle relaxants used during surgery.
  • It works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase at the neuromuscular junction, prolonging the action of acetylcholine and improving muscle strength.

Uses of Neostigmine:

  • Treatment of myasthenia gravis as it increases the availability of acetylcholine at neuromuscular junctions, thereby improving muscle strength.
  • To reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents after surgical procedures.
  • In managing urinary retention due to its ability to stimulate bladder muscle contractions.
  • Cobra bites because cobra toxin disrupts the neuromuscular junction, resulting in respiratory paralysis.

Bethanechol (Option A) is a cholinergic agonist that stimulates muscarinic receptors, which are found primarily in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts. It is not used to reverse muscle relaxation after surgery because it does not affect the neuromuscular junction.

Atropine (Option B) is a direct-acting anticholinergic (muscarinic antagonist), blocking the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors. It is used to treat bradycardia and to prevent the effects of excessive acetylcholine release. However, it does not reverse muscle relaxation.

Edrophonium (Option D) is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and is used as a diagnostic tool in suspected cases of myasthenia gravis (Tensilon test). It is administered intravenously to individuals suspected of myasthenia gravis. It temporarily improves muscle strength, confirming the diagnosis by demonstrating impaired neuromuscular transmission due to acetylcholine receptor deficiency.

questions.text: A primigravida came to the emergency department at 1 pm with a 5 cm dilated cervix and at 4 pm with 6 cm dilation, next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Intervention to be done

Explanation:

  • Patient is in active stage of labor (cervix 5 cm dilated)
  • In 3 hours, cervical dilation increased only 1 cm, indicating poor progress, which requires management steps.
  • Normal rate of cervical dilation in active labor is 1 cm/hour and descent is 1cm/hour

Management Principles:

  • If there is poor contraction and poor progress of labor, oxytocin is administered
  • If there are good contractions and poor progress of labor, cesarean section is advised

 

Slow progress of labor (Option A): This represents a diagnosis rather than a management plan. Simply identifying slow progress without implementing appropriate interventions does not address the underlying problem and may lead to prolonged labor with associated risks.

Wait for complete dilation (Option B): Expectant management is inappropriate when labor progression falls below accepted standards. Prolonged labor increases risks of maternal exhaustion, fetal distress, and other complications. Active intervention is necessary to prevent adverse outcomes.

Induce labor (Option C): Induction of labor is contraindicated as the patient is already in the active phase. Using induction agents in active labor could lead to uterine hyperstimulation and fetal compromise. The appropriate intervention would be either augmentation with oxytocin if contractions are inadequate, or consideration of cesarean delivery if cephalopelvic disproportion is suspected.

questions.text: The muscle attached to the marked bony structure is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ilio-psoas

Explanation:

  • The iliopsoas muscle consists of the illacus and psoas major muscles.
  • It attaches to the lesser trochanter of the femur and primarily originates from the iliac fossa and lumbar vertebrae.
  • The iliopsoas muscle is a major hip flexor and assists in anterior pelvic tilt.

Gluteus maximus (Option B): Gluteus maximus is inserted into the iliotibial tract and gluteal tuberosity of the femur.

Gluteus medius (Option C): Gluteus medius inserts into the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.

Sartorius (Option D): Sartorius inserts into the medial side of the proximal tibia.

questions.text: Which of the following mutations is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reciprocal translocation

Explanation:

  • The Philadelphia chromosome is a balanced translocation between the long arm of chromosomes 9 and 22 [t(9;22)(q34.1;q11.2)]. It is present in the majority of patients with chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML).

Formation of Philadelphia chromosome:

  • A balanced translocation is a type of chromosomal rearrangement in which segments of two different chromosomes break and exchange places without any loss of genetic material.
  • In the case of CML, a segment of chromosome 9 containing the ABL gene (Abelson Leukemia), located at the q34 region, moves to chromosome 22.
  • Similarly, the segment of chromosome 22 containing the BCR gene (breakpoint cluster region), located at the q11 region, moves to chromosome 9.
  • This exchange results in the formation of two derivative chromosomes: one with the truncated chromosome 9 segment and the BCR-ABL fusion gene and the other with the truncated chromosome 22 segment.
  • The chromosome containing the BCR-ABL fusion gene is known as the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

  • The BCR-ABL fusion forms a novel oncoprotein called p210bcr-abl-1 (210 = molecular weight in kiloDalton—210 kDa).

Inversion (Option A) occurs when a segment of DNA breaks away from the chromosome, flips around, and reattaches in the reverse orientation. This is not the mechanism involved in Philadelphia chromosome formation.

Insertion (Option B) involves the addition of extra nucleotides into a DNA sequence. This type of mutation can cause frameshift mutations but is not responsible for the Philadelphia chromosome.

Deletion (Option D) results in the loss of a segment of DNA from a chromosome. While deletions are important mutations, they do not cause the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which involves an exchange of genetic material between chromosomes.

questions.text: Which among the following drug is not used in the treatment of acne vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical Fluocinolone

Explanation:

  • Fluocinolone is a corticosteroid, which can cause steroid-induced acne (pustular eruptions).
  • Steroids exacerbate acne rather than treat it.

Grades

Lesions

Treatment

Grade I

Non-inflammatory lesions such as open (blackheads) and closed comedones (whiteheads)

Topical retinoids

(Tretinoin, Adapalene)

Grade II

Non-inflammatory lesions (comedones) + inflammatory lesions such as papules and few pustules.

Topical retinoids + Topical antibiotics

Grade III

Multiple inflammatory papules and pustules ± nodules (moderate)

Topical retinoids + Oral antibiotics ± Benzoyl peroxide

Grade IV

Nodules + Cysts

(Most severe form)

Oral retinoids

(Isotretinoin)

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazides in DCT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Blockade of Na Cl symporter

Explanation:

  • Thiazide diuretics primarily exert their effects by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron.
  • Na-Cl symporter normally facilitates the reabsorption of Na+ and Cl- from the filtrate back into the bloodstream.
  • By blocking this, thiazides reduce the reabsorption of Na+ and Cl-, leading to increased excretion of these ions in the urine.
  • This results in diuresis and a reduction in blood volume, helping to lower blood pressure and reduce edema (associated with CHF, hepatic cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, acute glomerulonephritis)

Blockade of Na Cl symporter (Option A): This is the mechanism of action of loop diuretics (like furosemide), which inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, not the distal convoluted tubule.

Blockade of aldosterone receptors (Option C): This describes the mechanism of aldosterone antagonists (like spironolactone), which block aldosterone receptors in the collecting duct and distal tubule, leading to increased sodium excretion and potassium retention.

Blockade of epithelial sodium channels (Option D): This refers to the action of amiloride, which is a potassium-sparing diuretic. They block the epithelial sodium channels in the distal convoluted tubule and collect the duct, reducing sodium reabsorption and preventing potassium loss.

questions.text: A teenager was brought to the OPD with complaints of delayed fertility and primary amenorrhea. Physical examination reveals a webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with a given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 45, X

Explanation:

  • The teenager presenting with delayed fertility, primary amenorrhea, a webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples is diagnosed with Turner Syndrome, which is characterised by the karyotype 45, X (monosomy X).
  • It is characterised by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism in phenotypic females.
  • Clinical features: Short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema, and primary amenorrhea.

 

The image below shows karyotyping in Turner syndrome.

 

47, XXY (Option B) is Klinefelter syndrome, which occurs in males with an extra X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism, small testes, gynecomastia, reduced body/facial hair, and infertility. While it is associated with tall stature and sometimes mild intellectual disabilities, it does not present with features like a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, or primary amenorrhea, which are characteristic of Turner syndrome.

47, XXX (Option C) is Triple X Syndrome, which occurs in females with an extra X chromosome. It is usually asymptomatic or causes mild developmental delays but does not present with primary amenorrhea or webbed neck, which are typical of Turner syndrome.

47, XYY (Option D) is Jacob's Syndrome, which occurs in males with an extra Y chromosome, leading to tall stature and mild intellectual disabilities, but it does not cause primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, or widely spaced nipples, which are characteristic of Turner syndrome.

questions.text: Dynein protein is an example of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transport protein

Explanation:

  • Dynein is best classified as a transport protein.
  • It is a motor protein that moves along microtubules in cells, transporting cellular cargo toward the minus end of these structures.
    • This function is essential for various intracellular transport processes, including the movement of organelles, vesicles, and other cellular components.
  • Dynein also plays a role in cell motility, such as the movement of cilia and flagella

Cell membrane protein (Option B): These proteins are involved in forming channels, receptors, and anchors in the cell membrane, but dynein operates within the cytoplasm, not at the membrane.

Cell organelle adherent protein (Option C): Dynein’s primary role is transport rather than adherence.

Intracellular junctional protein (Option D): These proteins are involved in cell-cell adhesion and communication (e.g., cadherins, connexins), whereas dynein's function is intracellular transport along the cytoskeleton.

questions.text: After cataract surgery, a patient develops endophthalmitis with vision limited to hand movements. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intravitreal antibiotic injections

Explanation: Acute endophthalmitis:

Definition
  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.
  • Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris
  • Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation
  • Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex
  • Raised intraocular pressure initially

Treatment

  • Intravitreal antibiotics (Option A):
    • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg
    • Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg
  • Topical antibiotics (Option D)
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Steroid Therapy
  • Supportive Therapy
  • Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours (Option B) or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face
  • If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

Redo surgery (Option C) is not the right surgical approach for endophthalmitis.

questions.text: The following image shows which X-ray view?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Towne view

  • Towne view is for mastoid and middle ear views
  • An X-ray view perpendicular to the orbito-meatal line is called submento vertical view or a Towne view.

 

Incorrect Options:

Waters view (Option A):

  • This is done in AP view which is also called as occipitomental view
  • It helps in evaluating the maxillary sinuses

Caldwell's view (Option B):

  • This is also an AP view and helps in looking at frontal and ethmoidal sinus evaluation

Hirtz view (Option D):

  • This is a submentovertical view
  • It helps in evaluating ethmoidal and sphenoid sinusitis

questions.text: Patient, who is on antipsychotic medication for his schizophrenia, started to have dystonia. Management of this patient is by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Benzhexol

Explanation:

  • Anticholinergic medications like benzhexol (which acts on the parasympathetic nervous system by inhibiting efferent pulses directly) can be used to treat Acute Dystonia.
  • It refers to brief, sudden muscle contractions that lead to abnormal movements or postures.
  • This extrapyramidal side effect, commonly seen with antipsychotic medications, occurs when there is a disruption in the nigrostriatal pathway, which plays a key role in motor control.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Oculogyric crises (upward rolling of eyes)
    • Tongue protrusion
    • Trismus (jaw muscles)
    • Torticollis (neck muscles twisting to one side)
    • Laryngospasm
    • Dysarthria, Dysphasia (glossopharyngeal symptoms)
    • Dystonic postures of the limbs and trunk.
  • Management:
    • Anticholinergic drugs:
      • Parenteral (IV or IM) is for immediate treatment
      • Oral is used for prophylaxis
      • Drugs include Benztropine, Diphenhydramine, and Promethazine.

 

Replace with fluphenazine (Option B): Fluphenazine is a first-generation antipsychotic primarily used to treat symptoms of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders.

Increase the dose of haloperidol (Option C): Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic (typical antipsychotic) effective for managing psychosis but is known for a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as dystonia, akathisia, and tardive dyskinesia.

Clozapine (Option D) is a second-generation antipsychotic specifically indicated for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is known for its efficacy in patients who do not respond to other antipsychotic medications. It can lead to a rare adverse effect, such as granulocytosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who is receiving cyclosporine A following renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of the treatment. Biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fibroadenoma

Explanation:

  • The biopsy image shows a proliferation of ducts arranged in both intracanalicular and pericanalicular patterns, surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma, suggesting Fibroadenoma. These tumours are common in young women, and hormonal changes may influence their growth. Cyclosporine A, which has hormonal effects, could contribute to the development of fibroadenoma.

Fibroadenoma:

  • It is the most common benign breast tumour, typically found in women aged 15-35.
  • Characteristics: Spherical masses measuring 1-10 cm, firm, non-tender, well-circumscribed, mobile and often single.
  • The lump is mobile and slippery and hence called breast mouse.
  • Estrogen sensitivity: Can increase in size during pregnancy, lactation, or estrogen therapy and usually regress after menopause.
  • HPE: Well-defined borders due to a fibrous capsule, with proliferating stroma potentially compressing and distorting glandular components.
  • Popcorn calcification on mammogram.
  • Ageing effect: Epithelium atrophies with age, and the stroma becomes more hyalinised.
  • Molecular alteration: Alterations in MED12 gene
  • Drug associated with bilateral fibroadenomas: Cyclosporine

The histological features of a fibroadenoma include:

  1. Fibroepithelial tumours are composed of benign-appearing cellular or myxoid stroma encircling epithelium-lined glands and cystic spaces.
  2. Staghorn clusters of cells - Ductal cells arranged in a deer horn-like pattern
  3. Bare nuclei - cytoplasm is stripped of,f and only nuclei are visible in blue colour.

Incorrect Options:

Fat necrosis (Option A) typically presents with firm, tender breast lumps following trauma or surgery and shows fatty tissue changes on biopsy, not ductal proliferation.

Phyllodes tumour (Option B) can have similar histological features with ductal proliferation but is typically more cellular and can have a leaf-like architecture. It also tends to grow rapidly and is more common in older women.

Carcinoma breast (Option D) would be expected to present with more aggressive histological features, such as invasion of surrounding tissue and atypical cells, rather than benign ductal proliferation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy who fell on an outstretched hand is now experiencing pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which bone is most likely fractured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Scaphoid

Explanation:

  • A key clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture is pain and tenderness in the anatomical snuff box (the depression at the base of the thumb). They are particularly common among young adults.

 

Scaphoid fracture

Site

  • Waist of scaphoid (most common)
  • Distal pole (Least common)
  • Proximal pole (high risk for avascular necrosis)

Mechanism of injury

Typically caused by a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) with the wrist in dorsiflexion.

Clinical features

  • It is more common in young adults, particularly athletes.
  • Pain and tenderness localised to the anatomical snuffbox (the depression between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and the abductor pollicis longus/extensor pollicis brevis).
  • Swelling and reduced range of motion at the wrist.

X-ray

There is a visible fracture line at the waist of the scaphoid, with possible cortical disruption or displacement; avascular necrosis may later appear as sclerosis in the proximal pole.

Management

Immobilisation by scaphoid cast (3-4 months)

Complications

  • Avascular necrosis (more common in the proximal pole)
  • Humpback deformity (displaced Scaphoid fracture)
  • Delayed and non-union
  • Wrist osteoarthritis

 

Lunate (Options A) involves hyperextension or compression of a preexisting abnormal lunate. The lunate bone comes out to lie in front of other carpal bones (while in perilunate dislocation, lunate remains in its place and the other carpal bones dislocate around it dorsally).

Pisiform (Options C) is a rare fracture that can result from a direct blow, leading to comminuted fractures, or from an indirect force due to an avulsion or pull of the flexor carpi ulnaris tendon.

Trapezoid (Options D) is rare due to a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice. Biliary atresia is suspected when jaundice is persistent and exceeds?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 weeks

Explanation:

  • Biliary atresia is a serious condition that causes bile ducts to become obstructed or absent, leading to cholestasis and liver damage. In newborns, jaundice that persists beyond 2 weeks is a key clinical sign of biliary atresia, as physiological jaundice typically resolves within the first 1-2 weeks of life.

Extra-Hepatic Biliary Atresia:

  • Also known as Non-Cystic Obliterative Cholangiopathy.
  • Characterised by complete obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts and intrahepatic ducts at the hilum.
  • Typically appear by 2 to 6 weeks of age
    • Jaundice (yellowish coloration of skin and sclera)
    • Abnormally pale stools
    • Dark urine
  • Commonly associated with polysplenia or asplenia

Investigations:

  1. Liver Function Tests:
    • Increased conjugated bilirubin.
    • Markers of cholestasis:
      • 5' nucleotidase
      • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
      • GGT (Gamma-glutamyl transferase):
        • Normal: Up to 40 U/L
        • 4x elevation: Intrahepatic causes
        • 10x elevation: Extrahepatic causes
        • Exception: Low in PFIC type I and II
  2. Ultrasound:
    • High-frequency USG (HUS) for neonatal cholestasis.
    • Fasting USG is the gold standard when biliary atresia is suspected.
    • Characteristic findings:
      • Triangular cord sign (hyperechoic areas indicating fibrous/atretic bile duct)
      • Non-visualized gallbladder/micro gallbladder/gallbladder ghost
  3. Radionucleotide Study:
    • HIDA Scan (Hepatobiliary scan with Tc labelled imino-di-acetic acid):
      • Used as a screening test.
      • Decreased tracer excretion due to obstruction
    • Phenobarbitone loading/priming (5 days) to improve tracer uptake
    • Used as a screening test, not specific
  4. Best Investigation:
    • Liver biopsy: IOC for confirming diagnosis.

Surgical Management:

  •  
  • Temporary procedure: Kasai procedure/hepaticojejunostomy
  • Definitive management: Liver transplantation
  • Kasai Procedure:
    • Temporary procedure
    • Creates communication between the liver and jejunum for bile drainage
    • Should be performed within 8 weeks after birth

questions.text: Choose the correct sequence with respect to the stages of changes that the breast undergoes in a female?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mamogenesis→lactogenesis→galactokinesis→galactopoiesis

Explanation:

Sequential Stages of Breast Changes:

  • Mamogenesis:
    • Growth of both ductal and lobuloalveolar system
    • An intact nerve supply is not essential for the growth of mammary glands during pregnancy
  • Lactogenesis:
    • The alveolar cells are the principal sites for the production of milk
    • Milk secretion actually starts on 3rd or 4th postpartum day
  • Galactokinesis:
    • Oxytocin is the major galactokinetic hormone
    • Discharge of milk from the mammary glands depends on suckling and contractile mechanism
  • Galactopoiesis:
    • Prolactin appears to be the single most important galactopoietic hormone
    • For maintenance of effective and continuous lactation, frequency of suckling (>8/24 hours) is essential

Options A, B & D are incorrect as they do not follow the physiological sequence of breast changes during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: In the presented spirometry image, what term corresponds to the point labeled F?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vital capacity

Explanation: Vital Capacity (VC) is the maximum amount of air that can be exhaled after a maximum inhalation and is calculated by summing Tidal Volume (TV), Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV), and Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV).

VC = TV + IRV + ERV

 

Lung Volume/Capacity

Description

Typical Volume (mL)

Formula

Tidal Volume (TV)

Amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breath

500

-

Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV)

Additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation

3000

-

Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV)

Additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation

1200

-

Residual Volume (RV)

Air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation

1200

-

Anatomical Dead Space

Volume of air in conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs

150

-

Total Lung Capacity (TLC)

Maximum amount of air the lungs can hold

6000

TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV

Vital Capacity (VC)

Maximum air exhaled after a maximal inhalation

4800

VC = TV + IRV + ERV

Inspiratory Capacity (IC)

Maximum air inhaled after a normal exhalation

3500

IC = TV + IRV

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

Air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation

2400

FRC = ERV + RV

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 22 weeks of gestation presents with a marginal placenta on ultrasound. When is the next ultrasound recommended for reassessment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 28 weeks

Explanation:

  • Marginal placenta is a Type 2 placenta previa where the placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Most cases resolve by 28-29 weeks of gestation
  • Resolution occurs due to placental migration through two mechanisms:
    1. Progressive increase in the length of the lower uterine segment causes the lower placental edge to relocate away from the cervical os
    2. Trophotropism (growth of trophoblastic tissue towards the fundus) leads to resolution of placenta previa.

Management Protocol:

If a marginal placenta is detected at 22 weeks:

  • First follow-up USG should be done at 28 weeks
  • If persistence is noted, another assessment is done at 38 weeks

questions.text: A married woman with a failed contraception method presents at 26 weeks of gestation. What is the appropriate course of action based on the MTP Act?

choices.text: If no fetal anomaly, continue the pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) If no fetal anomaly, continue the pregnancy

Explanation:

  • According to the latest amended MTP Act of 2023, willful termination of pregnancy is allowed up to 24 weeks of gestation
  • In this case, although contraceptive failure is an indication for medical termination, the gestational age (26 weeks) is beyond the legal limit of 24 weeks
  • Therefore, the pregnancy should be continued if there are no fetal anomalies

Other Indications for MTP:

  • Eugenic: Child is malformed
  • Teratogenic malformation
  • TORCH infections
  • Physical malformation
  • Therapeutic: Risk of life of the mother, physical or mental anomaly
  • Humanitarian: Rape

 

Husband consent (Option A):

  • The husband's consent is not required for MTP

2 doctors opinion (Option B):

  • Up to 20 weeks, a single doctor’s opinion is required. A minimum of 2 doctor’s opinions is required for 20-24 weeks.
  • Not applicable in this case as gestation is beyond 24 weeks

Medical board permission for termination (Option D):

  • Medical board permission for termination is required for special situations beyond 24 weeks of gestation
  • Not applicable here as there are no reported fetal anomalies

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low blood pressure. What is the correct JVP finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Absent y descent

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations such as muffled heart sounds with low blood pressure indicate cardiac tamponade, which is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, leading to compromised cardiac filling and subsequent hemodynamic compromise.
  • In cardiac tamponade, the characteristic finding is absent y descent and non-pulsatile elevated JVP due to impaired right ventricular filling during diastole. The condition presents with Beck's triad, which includes muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and elevated JVP.

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus Paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

 

Steep x descent (Option A): Steep x descent is typically seen in constrictive pericarditis. Although prominent x descent is also seen in cardiac tamponade, absent y descent is a more highlighting feature typical of cardiac tamponade.

Steep y descent (Option C): Steep y descent is observed in exaggerated tricuspid regurgitation, which allows for rapid right atrial emptying during diastole.

Blunted x descent (Option D): Blunted x descent is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy where there is impaired ventricular relaxation. The clinical presentation of muffled heart sounds and hypotension is more consistent with cardiac tamponade rather than restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for the use of bi-level positive airway pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Unconscious/sedation

 

Explanation:

 

  • BiPAP (bilevel positive airway pressure) therapy is best for short-term use and in patients who can cough and protect their airway.

 

  • Indications for using BiPAP machine
    • COPD
    • Obstructive sleep apnea (Option A)
    • Patients with conditions causing low partial pressure of oxygen (Option D)

 

  • Contraindications:

Absolute contraindication

Relative contraindication

Facial trauma/ burn

Altered mental staus/ unconscious (Option B)

Fixed upper airway obstruction

Inability to protect the airway

Active vomiting

Life threatening hypoxemia

Respiratory or cardiac arrest

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of the hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

Explanation

  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting step of the HMP pathway. It catalyzes the oxidation of glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphoglucono-δ-lactone, generating NADPH, which is critical for reductive biosynthesis and maintaining cellular redox balance.
  • The pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) is essential in erythrocytes because it generates NADPH. NADPH is crucial for maintaining glutathione in its reduced form, which is necessary for the activity of glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme removes harmful hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂), protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage and preventing hemolysis.

Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP)

The Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt, is an alternative metabolic pathway for glucose that doesn't generate ATP.

Location: Cytosol
It serves two primary functions:

NADPH Production
  • The PPP is a major source of NADPH, vital for biosynthesis (fatty acids and steroids).
  • NADPH Production: RBCs rely on glycolysis for ATP due to the lack of mitochondria and depend solely on the PPP for NADPH, as they lack mitochondrial dehydrogenases.
  • Glutathione Maintenance: NADPH keeps glutathione reduced, enabling glutathione peroxidase to neutralize hydrogen peroxide and prevent oxidative damage.
  • Impact of NADPH Deficiency: Low NADPH reduces glutathione, impairs glutathione peroxidase, increases oxidative damage, and leads to hemolysis.

Ribose-5-Phosphate (R-5-P) Synthesis
  • Ribose-5-phosphate is essential for nucleotide synthesis needed for RNA and DNA.

Homeostasis between NADPH and R-5-P

production.
  • When NADPH demand exceeds R-5-P's need, the non-oxidative phase converts R-5-P to glycolytic intermediates (fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate).
  • If the demand for R-5-P is higher than for NADPH, the non-oxidative phase generates R-5-P from fructose-6-phosphate and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate, bypassing the oxidative steps.

Differences from Glycolysis
  • Uses NADP+ instead of NAD+ and generates CO2, not ATP.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option A): This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose during gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. It is not involved in the HMP pathway.

Phosphofructokinase-1 (Option C): This enzyme is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis, not the HMP pathway.

Glycogen phosphorylase (Option D): This enzyme catalyzes the breakdown of glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in glycogenolysis and is not related to the HMP pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gynecomastia

Explanation:

  • Amiodarone is a potent antiarrhythmic drug used primarily for ventricular arrhythmias and atrial fibrillation.
  • While it has several potential side effects and a long half-life, gynecomastia is not one of the common adverse effects.

Amiodarone

MOA
  • It prolongs action potential duration and QT interval by blocking delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  • Blocks inactivated Na+ channels, with rapid channel recovery (Decrease phase 0 slope).
  • It partially inhibits myocardial Ca2+ channels, adding to its antiarrhythmic effects.
  • It is used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation.

Drug interactions
  • Inhibits CYP3A4, CYP2C9, and P-glycoprotein, leading to potential interactions with drugs metabolized by this system.
  • Increases plasma levels of digoxin and warfarin.
  • Additive AV block with beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

Adverse reactions
  • Hypotension and Bradycardia (with i.v administration or after drug accumulation)
  • Photosensitivity: Skin pigmentation - Purple colour (purple man syndrome, smurf syndrome)
  • Corneal microdeposits: Reversible upon drug discontinuation.
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis, on long-term use (Option D ruled out)
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Interfere with thyroid function as it acts as a source of iodine and can potentially lead to goitre, hypothyroidism (Wolf Chaikoff effect), or, in rare cases, hyperthyroidism (Jos-Basedow effect). (Option A and B ruled out)

questions.text: Drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aspirin

Explanation:

  • Aspirin is used in acute rheumatic fever (ARF) for its anti-inflammatory and antipyretic properties to control symptoms of arthritis and fever.
  • ARF is a complication of Group A Streptococcus (GAS) throat infection, often following untreated or inadequately treated strep throat.
  • The main goals in the treatment of ARF are to reduce inflammation, prevent further damage to the heart, and manage symptoms such as joint pain and fever.

Management of ARF

Treatment for

Medication used

Group streptococcal infection
  • Penicillin/Erythromycin/Azithromycin.
  • 10 days or oral Amoxicillin or a single dose of IM benzathine penicillin.
  • Azithromycin in case of Penicillin allergy.

Symptomatic management
  • Salicylates like aspirin (NSAIDs as an alternative option)
  • It is the first-line treatment for arthritis, fever, and inflammation. Dose: High initially, then taper as symptoms improve.

Carditis
  • Corticosteroids.
  • Diuretics like Furosemide are used if heart failure symptoms due to rheumatic carditis are present. (Option D ruled out)

Chorea
  • It is managed conservatively, or Valproic acid is used for the sedation

CCF

Diuretics and vasodilators are used.

Prophylaxis

(is essential to prevent recurrent infections and further damage to the heart)

Inj. Benzathine penicillin is given every 3-4 weeks IM

  • 6 lakh IU in children ≤27 kg.
  • 1.2 million IU in children >27 kg

Bed rest is advised

Digoxin (Option A) is a cardiac glycoside used to treat conditions like heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It is not used to treat acute rheumatic fever, unless there is heart failure due to rheumatic carditis. Even then, it would only be used as a supportive therapy, not as the primary treatment for ARF.


Amiodarone (Option C) is an antiarrhythmic drug mainly used for arrhythmias like ventricular tachycardia or atrial fibrillation. It may be used in patients with arrhythmias that can occur as a consequence of RHD, but it is not the drug of choice for treating acute rheumatic fever itself.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with ear pain and an HBA1c of 10 presents with excruciating ear pain and blood-stained ear discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Necrotizing otitis externa which is also known as malignant otitis externa

Explanation:

  • It is a pseudomonas infection
  • It is reddish polypoidal lesion at the junction of cartilage and bone which bleeds on touch, seen especially in diabetics and patients with uncontrolled HBA1c

 

Malignant (Necrotizing) Otitis Externa (MOE)

  • Inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas infection.
  • Commonly affects elderly diabetic patients or those on immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Severe ear pain, granulations in the ear canal, and facial paralysis are common symptoms.
  • Infection can spread to the skull base, jugular foramen, and cause multiple cranial nerve palsies.

Etiopathogenesis:

  • Early presentation mimics diffuse otitis externa but with intense pain.
  • Granulations in the ear canal indicate disease progression.
  • Infection can extend:
    • Anteriorly to the temporomandibular fossa.
    • Posteriorly to the mastoid.
    • Medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

Investigations:

  • Clinical suspicion based on severe otalgia and granulation tissue in elderly diabetics.
  • Imaging:
    • CT scan/MRI: Shows bone destruction and soft tissue involvement.
    • Gallium-67 scan: Indicates soft tissue infection; useful for diagnosis and follow-up.
    • Technetium-99 bone scan: Detects bone infection but not useful for disease monitoring due to prolonged positivity.

Treatment:

  • Control of diabetes: Essential for management.
  • Ear canal toilet: Clean the ear, remove discharge, debris, and granulations.
  • Antibiotics:
    • IV Gentamicin with Ticarcillin (both ototoxic/nephrotoxic).
    • Third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime), combined with an aminoglycoside.
    • Quinolones (e.g., Ciprofloxacin 750 mg orally) can be combined with Rifampin.
    • Antibiotic therapy typically lasts 6-8 weeks or longer.
  • Culture and sensitivity of ear discharge to adjust antibiotics if non-responsive to treatment.
  • Prolonged antibiotic treatment has largely replaced the need for radical surgery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Otitis externa (Option A):

  • It is characterized by pain during jaw movement and can be seen in diabetics but not associated with any blood stained- ear discharge

 

Serous otitis media (Option C):

  • Excrutuiation pain and blood stained ear discharge are not features of serous otitis media

 

Otomycosis (Option D):

  • It is caused by Aspergillus niger/ Candida species in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressant persons and most often in immunocompromised people.
  • It is characterized by white-ish discharge with black spores (Wet newspaper-like appearance) and the main symptom as itching in the external auditory canal.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man came for a follow-up after recently receiving a new diagnosis and treatment initiation. He is counseled about the Axshya project. Which of the following diseases was this patient diagnosed with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Tuberculosis

  • Project Axshya is a collaborative initiative aimed at improving TB control efforts in India. It focuses on strengthening TB care and control services, including early detection, diagnosis, and treatment of TB cases.
  • The project includes strategies such as community mobilization, awareness campaigns, and active case finding to reach vulnerable populations and reduce the TB burden.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D: Project Axshya does not deal with any of these diseases.
